from the \u00a321.4billion the company had proposed.\n\nOfwat said the increase in customers' bills it outlined on Thursday gave Thames Water the opportunity to 'make a fair set of returns' and it was investors and to seek to raise that funding,' Ofwat chief executive David Black told BBC radio.\n\nIn charge: Tim Weston is the chief executive of Thames Water\n\nTurbulence: Bosses are scrambling to secure a major cash injection to keep Thames Water afloat\n\nBosses are scrambling to secure a major cash injection to keep Thames Water afloat, and have held talks with both existing shareholders and external investors.\n\nBut chief executive Chris Weston said on Tuesday that the investment is 'dependent on [Thames Water] securing a final regulatory determination that is ... investable.'\n\nIf Thames Water does not succeed in getting the funding, it faces the prospect of being temporarily nationalised by the government and being placed in a form of special administration, meaning the taxpayer would take on the costs of the heavily loss-making water giant.\n\nOfwat's ruling on Thursday is a draft decision and kicks off a lengthy period of negotiations until its final verdict in December.\n\nBut, the regulator has rarely made major deviations between its draft and final rulings in previous years, meaning today's statement gives companies an indication of how lenient it is likely to be later on.\n\nDavid Black, chief executive of Ofwat said: 'Customers want to see radical change in the way water companies care for the environment.\n\n'Our draft decisions on company plans approve a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer service and the environment at a fair price for customers.\n\n'These proposals aim to deliver a 44 per cent reduction in spills from storm overflows compared to levels in 2021. We expect all companies to embrace innovation and go further and faster to reduce spills wherever possible.\n\n'Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for 9 reservoirs.\n\n'Let me be very clear to water companies. We will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes.'\n\nHousehold water bills to rise by \u00a319 a year under draft proposals\n\nHousehold water bills in England and Wales are to rise by an average \u00a319 a year over the next five years - a third less than the increase requested by companies, under draft proposals announced by Ofwat.\n\nOn Thursday, the regulator said water firms proposed increases averaging \u00a3144 over five years.\n\nFor example, Thames Water's proposed increase of \u00a3191 by 2030 has been reduced to \u00a399, while Severn Trent's proposed rise of \u00a3144 has been cut to \u00a393.\n\nThere are marked variations in price changes between firms.\n\nUnder the plans, Southern Water customers will face a \u00a3183 hike over five years, while Dwr Cymru customers' bills will go up by \u00a3137 and Yorkshire Water customers will pay \u00a3107 more.\n\nAt the other end of the scale, Affinity customers will an \u00a311 rise, while SES customers' bills will fall by \u00a334 on the previous five years.\n\nMike Keil, chief executive of the Consumer Council for Water, said: 'Millions of people will feel upset and anxious at the prospect of these water bill rises and question the fairness of them given some water companies' track record of failure and poor service.\n\n'Customers understand investment is urgently needed but they need reassurance that every pound of their money is going to be well spent.'\n\nDIY INVESTING PLATFORMSAJ BellAJ BellEasy investing and ready-made portfoliosLearn MoreLearn MoreHargreaves LansdownHargreaves LansdownFree fund dealing and investment ideasLearn MoreLearn Moreinteractive investorinteractive investorFlat-fee investing from \u00a34.99 per monthLearn MoreLearn MoreeToroeToroShare investing: 30+ million communityLearn MoreLearn MoreTrading 212Trading 212Free share dealing and no account feeLearn MoreLearn More\n\nAffiliate links: If you take out a product This is Money may earn a commission. a third less than the increase requested by companies, under the draft proposals.\n\nEnvironment Secretary Steve Reed will be meeting representatives from all 16 water companies from across England and Wales on Thursday following the Ofwat publication.\n\nA source close to Mr Reed said yesterday: \"The last Conservative government weakened regulation, allowing the sewage system to crumble and illegal sewage dumping to hit record levels.\n\n\"The election of this Labour Government is a reset moment for the water industry.\n\n\"In coming weeks and months, the Government will outline its first steps to reform the water sector to attract the investment we need to upgrade our infrastructure and restore our rivers, lakes and seas to good health.\"\n\nLet me be very clear to water companies -we will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes\n\nOfwat chief executive David Black said: \"Customers want to see radical change in the way water companies care for the environment.\n\n\"Our draft decisions on company plans approve a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer service and the environment at a fair price for customers.\n\n\"These proposals aim to deliver a 44% reduction in spills from storm overflows compared to levels in 2021. We expect all companies to embrace innovation and go further and faster to reduce spills wherever possible.\n\n\"Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for 9 reservoirs.\n\n\"Let me be very clear to water companies - we will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment {"uri": "8220511682", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "13:01:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T13:01:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T13:01:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/thames-water-bills-how-much-go-up-125328108.html", "title": "How high could your water bills go?", "body": "Regulators have rejected Thames Water's proposals to impose a 44% increase on bills, after the firm said it would run out of money by May 2025.\n\nBritain's biggest water firm, which has a debt pile of more than \u00a315bn, said on Tuesday that it had \u00a31.8bn of cash reserves at the end of June, a fall from \u00a32.4bn three months previously.\n\nThames Water said it is still looking for new funds needed to maintain and update its infrastructure, after investors pulled the plug on \u00a3500m of emergency cash earlier this year.\n\nThe firm had wanted to impose a 44% increase in bills over the next five years but on Thursday Ofwat imposed a \"turnaround oversight regime\" and instead proposed Thames increase average yearly bills by 23% to \u00a3535 over the period.\n\nWater firms have already announced proposals to raise prices, prompting concern that the water bills for millions of Brits could drastically increase over the next few years in an effort to plug debts.\n\nOfwat has told Thames that it must \"fully re-evaluate\" its current turnaround strategy, adding that the firm must publish a separate \"financial resilience plan\". Ofwat is also considering appointing a so-called independent monitor, which would have \"full access\" to the company's financial information, to report on its progress.\n\nThames will also have to provide a \"delivery action plan\", outlining how it intends to improve its performance on sewage spills and leakage, which has been among the worst in the industry in recent years.\n\nWater companies had requested increases averaging \u00a3144 over five years, but this too has been rejected by Ofwat, who have instead proposed that bills increase by an average of \u00a319 per year over the next five years. The 21% bill increase is a third less than what was requested by the companies.\n\nThe firms wanted to increase their total spending by \u00a329bn but Ofwat said its scrutiny of companies' cost proposals, to ensure they deliver efficiently, had led to a \u00a316bn reduction.\n\nA spokesperson for Water UK said Ofwat's decision means it \"will be repeating the mistakes of the past\". They said it amounted to \"the biggest ever cut in investment by Ofwat\".\n\nThe spokesperson added: \"For far too long, Ofwat has failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed and what it will take to deliver and maintain necessary infrastructure...\n\n\"Water companies are ready to invest in an unprecedented overhaul of the country's water and sewage infrastructure. Ofwat now needs to let them get on with it.\"\n\nThames Water has 16 million customers in London and the Thames Valley region in the South East. Its plans - now rejected - would've seen spending rise to \u00a319.8bn to update its infrastructure and reduce sewage spills. However, that would've also involved increasing customer bills by 44%.\n\nSouthern Water have already announced a 9% rise this year, adding an extra \u00a340 per year to customer bills. They blamed the increase on inflation and increased costs for energy, fuel and raw materials. However, they want a 91% increase in bills to \u00a3915 a year by 2030.\n\nThe chart below shows the average increase - or decrease - of customers' water bills in percentage terms.\n\nThe data below shows the draft proposals for the average bills customers will be charged by water and wastewater companies in England and Wales by 2029/30. The average bill for 2024/25 is also listed, along with the increase or decrease between the two figures:\n\nWater firms say they need to increase bills due to the need to spend money on replacing infrastructure. Increases will fund \u00a3100bn of spending over the period, which will include replacing ageing, leaking pipes and reducing sewage discharges into rivers and seas.\n\nHowever, the increases would come off the back of disastrous recent environmental records that sparked a nationwide scandal over pollution. Thames said pollution incidents increased to 350, up on 331 last year, which it blamed on a rainier-than-expected year. They say the number of \"serious pollutions\" decreased by 18%.\n\nAccording to Environment Agency data, 2023 was the worst year for sewage spills since records began. Sewage was discharged for some 3.6 million hours across England - a 105% increase from 1.7 million hours in 2022.\n\nWhat may be particularly galling for customers is that while water firms have generally been profitable, their profits have been put into dividends for shareholders rather than investing in improvements. In May, Severn Trent hiked its dividend to shareholders after profits rose by a fifth last year, despite sewage spills by the company rising by a third in 2023. With increased sewage spills, the firms are now asking the taxpayer to help bail them out of their financial difficulties.\n\nThe bill rises also come in the wake of huge bonus payouts for water firm bosses. Liv Garfield, chief executive of Severn Trent received a \u00a33.2m pay packet for 2023, which includes salary, bonuses and shares. Over the past four years she has earned nearly \u00a313m.\n\nLast month Susan Davy, the chief executive of Pennon - which owns South West Water - saw her pay package jump 58% after picking up a \u00a3298,000 shares bonus despite seeing pollution incidents nearly double at the firm last year.\n\nDespite the controversy, Water UK chief executive David Henderson defended asking customers to pay for what he described as \"important\" investment in the water network.\n\nWhen asked how water companies can justify rising bills on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, the head of the trade association for the water industry, said: \"We need to increase our water supply and if we don't make these investments we won't get it. Unfortunately the investment will paid for up front by the shareholders of the companies and then slowly recouped over time.\"\n\nLabour has already ruled out nationalising the water industry. In their manifesto, published during the general election campaign, the party said they want to end water companies \"self-monitoring\".\n\nLabour has said it will pursue criminal charges against water company executives responsible for persistent pollution. It also said in its manifesto that regulators would be given new powers to block bonuses against executives who pollute waterways.\n\nPrime minister Keir Starmer's official spokesman told reporters on Monday: \"The government has said in its manifesto that we will put failing water companies into special measures and they will have no choice but to clean up their act. We talked about giving regulators the power to block payment of bonuses to executives who pollute our waterways and impose automatic and severe fines on them for wrongdoing.\"", "source": {"uri": Ofwat is also considering appointing a so-called independent monitor, which would have \"full access\" to the company's financial information, to report on its progress.\n\nThames will also have to provide a \"delivery action plan\", outlining how it intends to improve its performance on sewage spills and leakage, which has been among the worst in the industry in recent years.\n\nWater companies had requested increases averaging \u00a3144 over five years, but this too has been rejected by Ofwat, who have instead proposed that bills increase by an average of \u00a319 per year over the next five years. The 21% bill increase is a third less than what was requested by the companies.\n\nThe firms wanted to increase their total spending by \u00a329bn but Ofwat said its scrutiny of companies' cost proposals, to ensure they deliver efficiently, had led to a \u00a316bn reduction.\n\nA spokesperson for Water UK said Ofwat's decision means it \"will be repeating the mistakes of the past\". They said it amounted to \"the biggest ever cut in investment by Ofwat\".\n\nThe spokesperson added: \"For far too long, Ofwat has failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed and what it will take to deliver and maintain necessary infrastructure...\n\n\"Water companies are ready to invest in an unprecedented overhaul of the country's water and sewage infrastructure. Ofwat now needs to let them get on with it.\"\n\nHow much could your water bills go up?\n\nThames Water has 16 million customers in London and the Thames Valley region in the South East. Its plans - now rejected - would've seen spending rise to \u00a319.8bn to update its infrastructure and reduce sewage spills. However, that would've also involved increasing customer bills by 44%.\n\nSouthern Water have already announced a 9% rise this year, adding an extra \u00a340 per year to customer bills. They blamed the increase on inflation and increased costs for energy, fuel and raw materials. However, they want a 91% increase in bills to \u00a3915 a year by 2030.\n\nThe chart below shows the average increase - or decrease - of customers' water bills in percentage terms.\n\nThe data below shows the draft proposals for the average bills customers will be charged by water and wastewater companies in England and Wales by 2029/30. The average bill for 2024/25 is also listed, along with the increase or decrease between the two figures:\n\nWater and wastewater companies:\n\nAnglian Water: 2024/25 \u00a3491, 2029/30 \u00a3557, up \u00a366\n\nDwr Cymru: 2024/25 \u00a3466, 2029/30 \u00a3603, up \u00a3137\n\nHafren Dyfrdwy: 2024/25 \u00a3396, 2029/30 \u00a3524, up \u00a3128\n\nNorthumbrian Water: 2024/25 \u00a3415, 2029/30 \u00a3460, up \u00a345\n\nSevern Trent Water: 2024/25 \u00a3403, 2029/30 \u00a3496, up \u00a393\n\nSouthern Water: 2024/25 \u00a3420, 2029/30 \u00a3603, up \u00a3183\n\nSouth West Water: 2024/25 \u00a3497, 2029/30 \u00a3561, up \u00a364\n\nThames Water: 2024/25 \u00a3436, 2029/30 \u00a3535, up \u00a399\n\nUnited Utilities: 2024/25 \u00a3442, 2029/30 \u00a3536, up \u00a394\n\nWessex Water: 2024/25 \u00a3508, 2029/30 \u00a3497, down \u00a312\n\nYorkshire Water: 2024/25 \u00a3430, 2029/30 \u00a3537, up \u00a3107\n\nWater-only companies:\n\nAffinity Water: 2024/25 \u00a3192, 2029/30 \u00a3203, up \u00a311\n\nPortsmouth Water: 2024/25 \u00a3114, 2029/30 \u00a3135, up \u00a321\n\nSouth East Water: 2024/25 \u00a3230, 2029/30 \u00a3248, up \u00a318\n\nSouth Staffs Water: 2024/25 \u00a3161, 2029/30 \u00a3183, up \u00a322\n\nSES Water: 2024/25 \u00a3221, 2029/30 \u00a3187, down \u00a334\n\nWhy are people so angry?\n\nWater firms say they need to increase bills due to the need to spend money on replacing infrastructure. Increases will fund \u00a3100bn of spending over the period, which will include replacing ageing, leaking pipes and reducing sewage discharges into rivers and seas.\n\nHowever, the increases would come off the back of disastrous recent environmental records that sparked a nationwide scandal over pollution. Thames said pollution incidents increased to 350, up on 331 last year, which it blamed on a rainier-than-expected year. They say the number of \"serious pollutions\" decreased by 18%.\n\nAccording to Environment Agency data, 2023 was the worst year for sewage spills since records began. Sewage was discharged for some 3.6 million hours across England - a 105% increase from 1.7 million hours in 2022.\n\nWhat may be particularly galling for customers is that while water firms have generally been profitable, their profits have been put into dividends for shareholders rather than investing in improvements. In May, Severn Trent hiked its dividend to shareholders after profits rose by a fifth last year, despite sewage spills by the company rising by a third in 2023. With increased sewage spills, the firms are now asking the taxpayer to help bail them out of their financial difficulties.\n\nThe bill rises also come in the wake of huge bonus payouts for water firm bosses. Liv Garfield, chief executive of Severn Trent received a \u00a33.2m pay packet for 2023, which includes salary, bonuses and shares. Over the past four years she has earned nearly \u00a313m.\n\nLast month Susan Davy, the chief executive of Pennon - which owns South West Water - saw her pay package jump 58% after picking up a \u00a3298,000 shares bonus despite seeing pollution incidents nearly double at the firm last year.\n\nDespite the controversy, Water UK chief executive David Henderson defended asking customers to pay for what he described as \"important\" investment in the water network.\n\nWhen asked how water companies can justify rising bills on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, the head of the trade association for the water industry, said: \"We need to increase our water supply and if we don't make these investments we won't get it. Unfortunately the investment will paid for up front by the shareholders of the companies and then slowly recouped over time.\"\n\nWhat has Starmer said about water companies?\n\nLabour has already ruled out nationalising the water industry. In their manifesto, published during the general election campaign, the party said they want to end water companies \"self-monitoring\".\n\nLabour has said it will pursue criminal charges against water company executives responsible for persistent pollution. It also said in its manifesto that regulators would be given new powers to block bonuses against executives who pollute waterways.\n\nPrime minister Keir Starmer's official spokesman told reporters on Monday: \"The government has said in its manifesto that we will put failing water companies into special measures and they will have no choice but to clean up their act. We talked about giving regulators the power to block payment of bonuses to executives who pollute our waterways and impose automatic and severe fines on them for wrongdoing.\"\n\nRead more\n\nSpills on the London stock market if necessary.\n\nThames will only be allowed to increase its bills by 22pc under a draft ruling from Ofwat, just half the 44pc increase it had requested as it battles to shore up its finances.\n\nThames had requested a bill rise of \u00a3191 from \u00a3436 to \u00a3627 but the regulator said the company should be only allowed a \u00a399 rise.\n\nThe company is facing crunch point for firms, which are under fire over sewage pollution and leaks and the bonuses and dividends they have been paying out to executives.\n\nAmong the reforms the Environment Secretary is set to announce on Thursday is ensuring water infrastructure funding is ringfenced and can only be spent on upgrades, as well as a change of company rules to ensure customers are at the heart of the companies' objectives.\n\nConsumers will also be given the power to summon bosses to meetings through new customer panels which are designed to hold firms to account while Labour also wants to more government weakened regulation allowing the sewage system to crumble and illegal sewage dumping to hit record levels.\n\n\"The election of this Labour government is a reset moment for the water industry.\n\n\"In coming weeks and months, the Government will outline its first steps to reform the water sector to attract the investment we need to upgrade our infrastructure and restore our rivers, lakes and seas to good health.\"\n\nFor Thames Water, which is gripped by a funding crisis, Ofwat's draft decision on Thursday could be crunch time.\n\nThe firm has 16 million customers in London and the Thames Valley region and its plans submitted to Ofwat propose raising their bills by 44% between now and 2030.\n\nThe average yearly bill for a Thames customer is \u00a3436 at the moment, but that would rise to \u00a3627 in five years under its plans before factoring in inflation.\n\nThe bills hike will help it fund \u00a319.8 billion of improvements to its network of drains, sewers and reservoirs.\n\nIt has also asked Ofwat to lower the amount it fines the water company for incidents such as sewage spills and leakages.\n\nThames warned on Tuesday that it has only enough money to last it until the end of May 2025 before it goes out of business.\n\nThe water firm is drowning in more than \u00a315 billion of debt, and said on Tuesday that it needs fresh investment in the coming months to keep it afloat.\n\nAlready, existing shareholders pulled the plug on \u00a3500 million-worth of emergency funding in March. Thames said Ofwat's initial assessments of its business plan had the company \"uninvestible\".\n\nIf it ultimately fails to attract fresh funding, Thames' fraying finances will present Sir Keir Starmer's newly elected Labour Government with a significant industrial crisis.\n\nA blueprint codenamed Project Timber was being drawn up in Whitehall in the spring, according to reports, which could see the company effectively nationalised.\n\nOfwat's ruling on Thursday is only a draft decision, and kicks off a period of negotiation until its final verdict in December.\n\nBut the regulator has rarely made major deviations between its draft and final rulings in previous years, meaning Thursday's statement will give all parties an indication of how lenient it is likely to be later on.\n\nThe draft decision comes against a backdrop of public anger over the water companies and their role in the degraded state of the country's rivers, lakes and coastal waters, which are facing a perfect storm of creaking water infrastructure, intensive farming, a growing population and climate change.\n\nNot a single river in England is considered to be in good overall health, and beauty spots including Windermere in the Lake District have been hit by sewage spills.\n\nFigures released earlier this year showed storm overflows - which release untreated wastewater into rivers and seas when there is heavy rain to prevent sewers becoming overwhelmed - dumped sewage into the environment for more than 3.6 million hours in 2023.\n\nThe releases are legal, but the environmental watchdog, the Office for Environmental Protection, is investigating the Environment Department (Defra), the Environment Agency and regulator Ofwat over possible failures in regulating sewer overflows.\n\nThey are concerned that discharges have been permitted more often than the \"exceptional circumstances\" allowed by law.\n\nWater utilities have also been hit by large fines for illegal pollution in recent years, with a record \u00a390 million handed to Southern Water in 2021 for 6,971 unpermitted sewage discharges.\n\nOther companies including Thames Water, Severn Trent, South West Water and Yorkshire Water have been handed fines that ran into the millions for massive, damaging or repeated pollution incidents.", "source": {"uri": "uk.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/10/ofwat-to-issue-bills-ruling-as-water-firms-to-meet-environment-secretary/", "title": "Ofwat to issue bills ruling as water firms to meet Environment Secretary", "body": "The regulator will set out by how much England's suppliers can raise consumer bills over the next five years in a draft ruling.\n\nWater firms including embattled giant Thames Water will learn on Thursday how much they will be able to hike bills as Ofwat releases its ruling on the industry's future spending plans.\n\nThe regulator will publish a draft decision at 7am on its price review, setting out how far England's suppliers can raise consumer bills over the next five years and how much they can spend on updating their ageing infrastructure.\n\nLater the same day Environment Secretary Steve Reed is to meet all the water companies in England and Wales to discuss reforms aimed at stopping the \"unacceptable destruction of our waterways\".\n\nAmong the reforms the Environment Secretary is set to announce on Thursday is ensuring water infrastructure funding is ringfenced and can only be spent on upgrades, as well as a change of company rules to ensure customers are at the heart of the companies' objectives.\n\nConsumers will also be given the power to summon bosses to meetings through new customer panels which are designed to hold firms to account while Labour also wants to more than double compensation when water companies fail to meet key standards.\n\nThe Environment Secretary has promised to \"never look the other way while water companies pump sewage into our rivers, lakes and seas\".\n\nMr Reed added: \"This unacceptable destruction of our waterways should never have been allowed, but change has now begun so it can never happen again.\n\n\"Today I have announced significant steps to clean up the water industry to cut sewage pollution, protect customers and attract investment to upgrade its crumbling infrastructure.\n\n\"That change will take time. Over the coming weeks and months, this Government will outline further steps to reform the water sector and restore our rivers, lakes and seas to good health.\"\n\nThe firm has 16 million customers in London and the Thames Valley region and its plans submitted to Ofwat propose raising its bills by 44% between now and 2030.\n\nThe average yearly bill for a Thames customer is \u00a3436 at the moment, but that would rise to \u00a3627 in five years under the proposals before factoring in inflation.\n\nThe firm said the bills hike will help fund \u00a319.8 billion of improvements to its network of drains, sewers and reservoirs.\n\nIt has also asked Ofwat to lower the amount it fines the water company for incidents such as sewage spills and leakages.\n\nThames warned on Tuesday that it has only enough money to last it until the end of May 2025 before it goes out of business.\n\nThe water firm is drowning in more than \u00a315 billion of debt, and said on Tuesday that it needs fresh investment in the coming months to keep it afloat.\n\nAlready, existing shareholders pulled the plug on \u00a3500 million worth of emergency funding in March.\n\nThames said Ofwat's initial assessments of its business plan had made the company \"uninvestable\".\n\nIf it ultimately fails to attract fresh funding, Thames' fraying finances will present Sir Keir Starmer's newly elected Labour Government with a significant industrial crisis.\n\nOfwat's ruling on Thursday is only a draft decision, and kicks off a period of negotiation until its final verdict in December.\n\nBut the regulator has rarely made major deviations between its draft and final rulings in previous years, meaning Thursday's statement will give all parties an indication of how lenient it is likely to be later on.\n\nThe draft decision comes against a backdrop of public anger over the water companies and their role in the degraded state of the country's rivers, lakes and coastal waters, which are facing a perfect storm of creaking water infrastructure, intensive farming, a growing population and climate change.\n\nNot a single river in England is considered to be in good overall health, and beauty spots including Windermere in the Lake District have been hit by sewage spills.\n\nFigures released earlier this year showed storm overflows - which release untreated wastewater into rivers and seas when there is heavy rain to prevent sewers becoming overwhelmed - dumped sewage into the environment for more than 3.6 million hours in 2023.\n\nThe releases are legal, but environmental watchdog the Office for Environmental Protection is investigating the Environment Department (Defra), the Environment Agency and Ofwat over possible failures in regulating sewer overflows.\n\nIt is concerned that discharges have been permitted more often than the \"exceptional circumstances\" allowed by law.\n\nWater utilities have also been hit by large fines for illegal pollution in recent years, with a record \u00a390 million fine handed to Southern Water in 2021 for 6,971 unpermitted sewage discharges.\n\nOther companies including Thames Water, Severn Trent, South West Water and Yorkshire Water A bailout would cost an estimated \u00a35bn, much of which would likely be borne by the taxpayer.\n\nIf this happened, the company would likely be placed into a special administration regime, although there is currently no detail of what this could mean. This scheme was previously used to rescue energy supplier Bulb in 2021 before it was later sold to Octopus Energy.\n\nThe Government has so far refused to spell out what special measures would involve but Jonathan Reynolds, the Business Secretary, said prior to the general election that Labour would not want to see a nationalisation.\n\nHowever some believe that Thames Water could be renationalised permanently. as he meets water chiefs", "body": "Steve Reed will meet water bosses as Ofwat sets out how far England's water suppliers can raise consumer bills over the next five years.\n\nNew Environment Secretary Steve Reed will set out reforms aimed at stopping the \"unacceptable destruction of our waterways\" as he meets all the water companies in England and Wales.\n\nMr Reed will meet with executives at a crunch point for embattled water firms, which are under fire over sewage pollution and leaks, their demands to be able to put up bills for investment in ageing infrastructure and the bonuses and dividends they have been paying out.\n\nAmong the reforms the new Environment Secretary is set to announce on Thursday are ensuring water infrastructure funding is ringfenced and can only been spent on upgrades, as well a a change of company rules to ensure customers are at the heart of the companies' objectives, and that consumers have the power to summon bosses to meetings.\n\nMr Reed will meet the companies as Ofwat releases its draft decision on the water industry's future spending plans, setting out how far England's suppliers can raise consumer bills over the next five years and how much they can spend on updating their ageing infrastructure.\n\nLabour is casting its electoral win as a \"reset moment\" for the water industry according to a source close to Mr Reed, and it has promised to set out further plans to reform the sector in the coming weeks and months.\n\nThe Environment Secretary has meanwhile promised to \"never look the other way while water companies pump sewage into our rivers, lakes and seas\".\n\nMr Reed added: \"This unacceptable destruction of our waterways should never have been allowed, but change has now begun so it can never happen again.\n\n\"Today I have announced significant steps to clean up the water industry to cut sewage pollution, protect customers and attract investment to upgrade its crumbling infrastructure.\n\n\"That change will take time. Over the coming weeks and months, this Government will outline further steps to reform the water sector and restore our rivers, lakes and seas to good health.\"\n\nFor Thames Water, which is gripped by a funding crisis, Ofwat's draft decision on Thursday could be crunch time.\n\nThe firm has 16 million customers in London and the Thames Valley region and its plans submitted to Ofwat propose raising their bills by 44% between now and 2030.\n\nThe average yearly bill for a Thames customer is \u00a3436 at the moment, but that would rise to \u00a3627 in five years under its plans before factoring in inflation.\n\nThe bills hike will help it fund \u00a319.8 billion of improvements to its network of drains, sewers and reservoirs.\n\nIt has also asked Ofwat to lower the amount it fines the water company for incidents such as sewage spills and leakages.\n\nThames warned on Tuesday that it has only enough money to last it until the end of May 2025 before it goes out of business.\n\nThe water firm is drowning in more than \u00a315 billion of debt, and said on Tuesday that it needs fresh investment in the coming months to keep it afloat.\n\nAlready, existing shareholders pulled the plug on \u00a3500 million-worth of emergency funding in March. Thames said Ofwat's initial assessments of its business plan had made the company \"uninvestible\".\n\nIf it ultimately fails to attract fresh funding, Thames' fraying finances will present Sir Keir Starmer's newly elected Labour Government with a significant industrial crisis.\n\nA blueprint codenamed Project Timber was being drawn up in Whitehall in the spring, according to reports, which could see the company effectively nationalised.\n\nOfwat's ruling on Thursday is only a draft decision, and kicks off a period of negotiation until its final verdict in December.\n\nBut the regulator has rarely made major deviations between its draft and final rulings in previous years, meaning Thursday's statement will give all parties an indication of how lenient it is likely to be later on.\n\nThe draft decision comes against a backdrop of public anger over the water companies and their role in the degraded state of the country's rivers, lakes and coastal waters, which are facing a perfect storm of creaking water infrastructure, intensive farming, a growing population and climate change.\n\nNot a single river in England is considered to be in good overall health, and beauty spots including Windermere in the Lake District have been hit by sewage spills.\n\nFigures released earlier this year showed storm overflows - which release untreated wastewater into rivers and seas when there is heavy rain to prevent sewers becoming overwhelmed - dumped sewage into the environment for more than 3.6 million hours in 2023.\n\nThe releases are legal, but the environmental watchdog, the Office for Environmental Protection, is investigating the Environment Department (Defra), the Environment Agency and regulator Ofwat over possible failures in regulating sewer overflows.\n\nThey are concerned that discharges have been permitted more often than the \"exceptional circumstances\" allowed by law.\n\nWater utilities have also been hit by large fines for illegal pollution in recent years, with a record \u00a390 million handed to Southern Water in 2021 for 6,971 unpermitted sewage discharges.\n\nOther companies including Thames Water, Severn Trent, South West Water and Yorkshire Tuesday that it needs fresh investment in the coming months to keep it afloat.\n\nAlready, existing shareholders pulled the plug on \u00a3500 million-worth of emergency funding in March. Thames said Ofwat's initial assessments of its business plan had the company \"uninvestible\".\n\nIf it ultimately fails to attract fresh funding, Thames' fraying finances will present Sir Keir Starmer's newly elected Labour Government with a significant industrial crisis.\n\nA blueprint codenamed Project Timber was being drawn up in Whitehall in the spring, according to reports, which could see the company effectively nationalised.\n\nOfwat's ruling on Thursday is only a draft decision, and kicks off a period of negotiation until its final verdict in December.\n\nBut the regulator has rarely made major deviations between its draft and final rulings in previous years, meaning Thursday's statement will give all parties an indication of how lenient it is likely to be later on.\n\nThe draft decision comes against a backdrop of public anger over the water companies and their role in the degraded state of the country's rivers, lakes and coastal waters, which are facing a perfect storm of creaking water infrastructure, intensive farming, a growing population and climate change.\n\nNot a single river in England is considered to be in good overall health, and beauty spots including Windermere in the Lake District have been hit by sewage spills.\n\nFigures released earlier this year showed storm overflows - which release untreated wastewater into rivers and seas when there is heavy rain to prevent sewers becoming overwhelmed - dumped sewage into the environment for more than 3.6 million hours in 2023.\n\nThe releases are legal, but the environmental watchdog, the concerned that discharges have been permitted more often than the \"exceptional circumstances\" allowed by law.\n\nWater utilities have also been hit by large fines for illegal pollution in recent years, with a record \u00a390 million handed to Southern Water in 2021 for 6,971 unpermitted sewage discharges.\n\nOther companies including Thames Water, Severn Trent, South West Water and Yorkshire They had wanted to raise bills by an average of 33%, to invest 105 billion pounds.\n\nBritain's water industry has been in the firing line over the amount of sewage dumped in its waterways, with critics saying the companies have under-invested for decades while taking out billions of pounds in dividends and paying large bonuses to executives.\n\nOfwat boss David Black told Times Radio the \"rivers, lakes and seas to good health.\"\n\nThe crisis poses a challenge for new Prime Minister Keir Starmer who wants to boost private investment in Britain, with investors looking at water as a present Sir Keir Starmer's newly elected Labour Government with a significant industrial crisis.\n\nA blueprint codenamed Project Timber was being drawn up in Whitehall in the spring, according to reports, which could see the company effectively nationalised.\n\nUnder the plans, the company would be placed in a form of special administration in the scenario that its parent company fails.\n\nMr Weston added that it is \"not in the interests\" of customers or investors for the company to fall into Government hands.\n\nCommunities minister Jim McMahon said on Tuesday morning: \"We recognise that, over the last 14 years, frankly, the water industry hasn't been regulated anywhere near as firmly as it should have been, and we haven't seen the investment to deal with the sewage scandal.\"\n\nHe said there is a need for reform and for regulation to be looked at, adding: \"The days of putting shareholder interest above the national interest, frankly, can't carry on and so we do need to look at that and Thames do need to look at their own house and get it in order.\"\n\nMr McMahon said there is \"no programme of nationalisation for the water industry\" when asked what the plan is if the company collapses.\n\nHe did however say there is \"no provision in law for a water company to stop providing water\", adding: \"We need to be very clear there is always a contingency in place.\"\n\nThames Water's financial update will be followed on Thursday by a draft verdict from Ofwat on water companies' five-year spending plans and bill increases to 2030.\n\nThat will kick off six months of negotiations with Ofwat, ahead of its final decision in December.\n\nThames Water, which has 16 million customers in London and the Thames Valley region, put forward plans in April that would see spending rise to \u00a319.8 billion to update its infrastructure and reduce sewage spills.\n\nHowever, that would also involve increasing customer bills by 44%, a figure which has prompted backlash from consumer groups.\n\nMeanwhile, the process of securing new cash is \"not expected to conclude\" until after Ofwat's final decision on Thames' business plan in December.\n\nAny increase in bills would be greeted with anger, after Thames Water and other water companies' disastrous recent environmental records sparked a nationwide scandal over pollution.\n\nThames said pollution incidents increased to 350, up on 331 last year, which it blamed on a rainier-than-expected year.\n\nThe number of \"serious pollutions\" decreased by 18%, Thames Water said.\n\nWhen questioned on the issue on Tuesday, Mr Weston said: \"You might not like the answer, but rain has a big impact on spills.\"\n\nIt comes amid reports that Sir Keir has been briefed that the poor state of Thames Water's Our draft decisions on company plans approve a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer service and the environment at a fair price for customers.\n\n\"These proposals aim to deliver a 44% reduction in spills from storm overflows compared to levels in 2021. We expect all companies to embrace innovation and go further and faster to reduce spills wherever possible.\n\n\"Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for nine reservoirs.\n\n\"Let me be very clear to water companies - we will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes.\"\n\nA Water UK spokesman said: \"Today's announcement is the biggest ever cut in investment by Ofwat. If it doesn't put this right Ofwat will be repeating the mistakes of the past. As a direct result, more housing will be blocked, the recovery of our rivers will be slower and we will fail to deal with the water shortages we know are coming.\n\n\"Water companies proposed to invest \u00a3105 billion because it is the minimum needed to meet the legitimate concerns we've heard from the public about our environment and our economy.\n\n\"Ofwat is right to want to ensure customers receive value for money and that is why protections are in place to ensure customers only pay for projects that are new, necessary and value for money.\n\n\"But for far too long Ofwat has failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed and what it will take to deliver and maintain necessary infrastructure. We cannot allow this pattern to repeat itself.\n\n\"Water companies are ready to invest in an unprecedented overhaul of the country's water and sewage infrastructure. Ofwat now needs to let them get on with it.\"\n\nMike Keil, chief executive of the Consumer Council for Water (CCW), said: \"Millions of people will feel upset and anxious at the prospect of these water bill rises and question the fairness of them given some water companies' track record of failure and poor service.\n\n\"Customers understand investment is urgently needed but they need reassurance that every pound of their money is going to be well spent.\n\n\"Trust in water companies has never been lower and that won't change until people see and experience a difference - whether that's having the confidence to swim at their favourite beach or receiving help if they are struggling to pay their bill.\n\n\"We estimate about two million households in England and Wales currently cannot afford their water bill and, while the increase in financial assistance is welcome, it falls short of what is needed.\n\n\"Over the summer we'll be carrying out research with customers of every water company to gauge whether they feel the regulator's proposals are affordable and deliver what people want. decision at the end of the year.\n\nOfwat said the average 21% bill increase, around \u00a319 per year, follows firms' proposals to increase their total spending by \u00a329 billion, split between a \u00a35 billion increase in the core costs for running their business and a \u00a324 billion rise in spending to meet requirements set by governments and for other environmental improvements.\n\nOfwat said its scrutiny of companies' cost proposals, to ensure they deliver efficiently, has led to a \u00a316 billion reduction.\n\nHowever the proposed bill increases come amid public fury around firms' Our draft decisions on company plans approve a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer service and the environment at a fair price for customers.\n\n\"These proposals aim to deliver a 44% reduction in spills from storm overflows compared to levels in 2021. We expect all companies to embrace innovation and go further and faster to reduce spills wherever possible.\n\n\"Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for nine reservoirs.\n\n\"Let me be very clear to water companies - we will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes.\"\n\nA Water UK spokesman said: \"Today's announcement is the biggest ever cut in investment by Ofwat. If it doesn't put this right Ofwat will be repeating the mistakes of the past. As a direct result, more housing will be blocked, the recovery of our rivers will be slower and we will fail to deal with the water shortages we know are coming.\n\n\"Water companies proposed to invest \u00a3105 billion because it is the minimum needed to meet the legitimate concerns we've heard from the public about our environment and our economy.\n\n\"Ofwat is right to want to ensure customers receive value for money and that is why protections are in place to ensure customers only pay for projects that are new, necessary and value for money.\n\n\"But for far too long Ofwat has failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed and what it will take to deliver and maintain necessary infrastructure. We cannot allow this pattern to repeat itself.\n\n\"Water companies are ready to invest in an unprecedented overhaul of the country's water and sewage infrastructure. Ofwat now needs to let them get on with it.\"\n\nMike Keil, chief executive of the Consumer Council for Water (CCW), said: \"Millions of people will feel upset and anxious at the prospect of these water bill rises and question the fairness of them given some water companies' track record of failure and poor service.\n\n\"Customers understand investment is urgently needed but they need reassurance that every pound of their money is going to be well spent.\n\n\"Trust in water companies has never been lower and that won't change until people see and experience a difference - whether that's having the confidence to swim at their favourite beach or receiving help if they are struggling to pay their bill.\n\n\"We estimate about two million households in England and Wales currently cannot afford their water bill and, while the increase in financial assistance is welcome, it falls short of what is needed.\n\n\"Over the summer we'll be carrying out research with customers of every water company to gauge whether they feel the regulator's proposals are affordable and deliver what people want. We expect Ofwat to listen and act on what customers tell us.\"\n\nThe proposals are part of the 2024 Price Review (PR24) and cover the period from 1 April 2025 to 31 March 2030, ahead of a final decision at the end of the year.\n\nOfwat said the average 21% bill increase, around \u00a319 per year, follows firms' proposals to increase their total spending by \u00a329 billion, split between a \u00a35 billion increase in the core costs for running their business and a \u00a324 billion rise in spending to meet requirements set by governments and for other environmental improvements.\n\nOfwat said its scrutiny of companies' cost proposals, to ensure they deliver efficiently, has led to a \u00a316 billion reduction.\n\nHowever the proposed bill increases come amid public fury around firms' polluting of waterways with sewage spills as they continue to hand dividends to shareholders, and bonuses to executives - something which Labour has pledged to clamp down on.\n\nSewage spills into England's rivers and seas more than doubled in 2023.\n\nAccording to the Environment Agency, there were 3.6 million hours of spills last year - equal to about 400 years - compared with 1.75 million hours in 2022.\n\nThe large amount of water lost to leaks in the system also raises widespread concerns, particularly in dry periods when consumers face hosepipe bans.", "source": {"uri": responsible for 16,990 sewage discharges last year compared to 8,015 in 2022 while serious pollution incidents rose from 331 to 350 in that time.\n\nIt also comes as the company warned on Tuesday that it will run out of money by the end of next May due to their increasing debt and falling cash reserves, with their efforts to secure fresh funding intensifying.\n\nThames Water's bonus payments were revealed in its full-year results on Thursday and showed that Mr Weston received \u00a3195,000 following his appointment in January, taking his total pay to \u00a3437,000 for the three months to the end of March.\n\nAlastair Cochran, Thames Water's chief financial officer, was given a \u00a3446,000 bonus, after previously stepping in as the company's interim co-chief executive.\n\nWhen asked about executives bonuses on Tuesday, Mr Weston said: \"You need to be able to attract the right talent, the best talent to that company and going hand in glove with that is an appropriate remuneration package.\"\n\nThames Water is creaking under a debt pile of more than \u00a315 billion and said on Tuesday that it had \u00a31.8 billion of cash reserves at the end of June, a fall from \u00a32.4 billion three months previously.\n\nThe firm said it is still looking for new funds needed to maintain and update its infrastructure, after investors pulled the plug on \u00a3500 million of emergency cash earlier this year.\n\nMr Weston said Thames had taken \"informal soundings which have shown there is interest in the market\".\n\nHe added that the company will be looking at a \"broad church\" of potential investors which could include existing shareholders.\n\nIf it ultimately fails to attract fresh funding, Thames Water's fraying finances could present Sir Keir Starmer's newly elected Labour Government with a significant industrial crisis.\n\nA blueprint codenamed Project Timber was being drawn up in Whitehall in the spring, according to reports, which could see the company effectively nationalised.\n\nUnder the plans, the company would be placed in a form of special administration in the scenario that its parent company fails.\n\nMr Weston added that it is \"not in the interests\" of customers or investors for the company to fall into Government hands.\n\nCommunities minister Jim McMahon said on Tuesday morning: \"We recognise that, over the last 14 years, frankly, for regulation to be looked at, adding: \"The days of putting shareholder interest above the national interest, frankly, can't carry on and so we do need to look at that and Thames do need to look at We will get a grip of that.\"\n\nThe regulator said water firms had proposed increases averaging \u00a3144 over five years.\n\nFor example, Thames Water's planned rise of \u00a3191 by 2030 has been reduced to \u00a399, while Severn Trent's proposed increase of \u00a3144 has been cut to \u00a393.\n\nThere are significant variations in price changes between suppliers.\n\nUnder the plans, Southern Water customers will face a \u00a3183 increase over five years, while Dwr Cymru customers' bills will go up by \u00a3137 and Yorkshire Water customers will pay \u00a3107 more.\n\nAt the other end of the scale, Affinity customers will see just an \u00a311 rise, while SES customers' bills will fall by \u00a334 on the previous five years.\n\nOfwat chief executive David Black said: \"Customers want to see radical change in the way water companies care for the environment. Our draft decisions on company plans approve a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer service and the environment at a fair price for customers.\n\n\"These proposals aim to deliver a 44% reduction in spills from storm overflows compared to levels in 2021. We expect all companies to embrace innovation and go further and faster to reduce spills wherever possible.\n\n\"Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for nine reservoirs.\n\n\"Let me be very clear to water companies - we will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes.\"\n\nA Water UK spokesman said: \"Today's announcement is the biggest ever cut in investment by Ofwat. If it doesn't put this right Ofwat will be repeating the mistakes of the past. As a direct result, more housing will be blocked, the recovery of our rivers will be slower and we will fail to deal with the water shortages we know are coming.\n\n\"Water companies proposed to invest \u00a3105 billion because it is the minimum needed to meet the legitimate concerns we've heard from the public about our environment and our economy.\n\n\"Ofwat is right to want to ensure customers receive value for money and that is why protections are in place to ensure customers only pay for projects that are new, necessary and value for money.\n\n\"But for far too long Ofwat has failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed and what it will take to deliver and maintain necessary infrastructure. We cannot allow this pattern to repeat itself.\n\n\"Water companies are ready to invest in an unprecedented overhaul of the country's water and sewage infrastructure. Ofwat now needs to let them get on with it.\"\n\nMike Keil, chief executive of the Consumer Council for Water (CCW), said: \"Millions of people will feel upset and anxious at the prospect of these water bill rises and question the fairness of them given some water companies' track record of failure and poor service.\n\n\"Customers understand investment is urgently needed but they need reassurance that every pound of their money is going to be well spent.\n\n\"Trust in water companies has never been lower and that won't change until people see and experience a difference - whether that's having the confidence to swim at their favourite beach or receiving help if they are struggling to pay their bill.\n\n\"We estimate about two million households in England and Wales currently cannot afford their water bill and, while the increase in financial assistance is welcome, it falls short of what is needed.\n\n\"Over the summer we'll be carrying out research with customers of every water company to gauge whether they feel the regulator's proposals are affordable and deliver what people want. We expect Ofwat to listen and act on what customers tell us.\"\n\nThe proposals are part of the 2024 Price Review (PR24) and cover the period from 1 April 2025 to 31 March 2030, ahead of a final decision at the end of the year.\n\nOfwat said the average 21% bill increase, around \u00a319 per year, follows firms' proposals to increase their total spending by \u00a329 billion, split between a \u00a35 billion increase in the core costs for running their business and a \u00a324 billion rise in spending to meet requirements set by governments and for other environmental improvements.\n\nOfwat said its scrutiny of companies' cost proposals, to ensure they deliver efficiently, has led to a \u00a316 billion reduction.\n\nHowever the proposed bill increases come amid public fury around firms' polluting of waterways with sewage spills as they continue to hand dividends to shareholders, and bonuses to executives - something which Labour has pledged to clamp down on.\n\nSewage spills into England's rivers and seas more than doubled in 2023.\n\nAccording to the Environment Agency, there were 3.6 million hours of spills last year - equal to about 400 years - compared with 1.75 million hours in 2022.\n\nThe large amount of water lost to leaks in the system also raises widespread concerns, particularly in dry periods when consumers face hosepipe bans.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", Mr Weston further commented that it wouldn't be beneficial for either customers or investors for the company to fall into Government ownership.\n\nCommunities minister Jim McMahon said: \"We recognise that, over the last 14 years, frankly, the water industry hasn't been regulated anywhere near as firmly as it should have been, and we haven't seen the investment to deal with the sewage scandal.\"\n\n\"The days of putting shareholder interest above the national interest, frankly, can't carry on and so we do need to look at that and Thames do need to look at their own house and get it in order.\" When probed about the potential collapse of the company, Mr McMahon made it clear there is \"no programme of nationalisation for the water industry\".\n\nHe did however say there is \"no provision in law for a water company to stop providing water\", adding: \"We need to be very clear there is always a contingency in place.\" Thames Water's financial situation will come under further scrutiny on Thursday when Ofwat issues its preliminary assessment of water companies' five-year plans, which includes proposed bill increases up until 2030.\n\nThis announcement will initiate half a year of discussions with Ofwat, culminating in a final decision this December. Thames Water, serving 16 million customers across London and the Thames Valley, has pitched a plan in April to hike spending to \u00a319.8 billion to modernise infrastructure and cut down on sewage leaks.\n\nYet, this proposal comes with a 44% increase in customer bills, sparking outrage among consumer advocacy groups. The quest for fresh funding is \"not expected to conclude\" until after Ofwat's final verdict on Thames' business strategy in December. Households cannot choose their supplier; it depends on their location.\n\nThe water regulator Ofwat determines the service levels and costs to maintain efficient services through five-year \"price reviews.\" Each water company creates a five-year plan for services and household bills.\n\nWhile Ofwat sets limits, water and sewerage companies in England and Wales ultimately decide household charges. As a result, bills vary regionally, with factors like inflation, company performance and household income affecting individual payments.\n\nOfwat's proposals are part of the 2024 Price Review (PR24) and cover the period from 1 April 2025 to 31 March 2030, ahead of a final decision at the end of the year.\n\nOfwat said that water bills will go up by an average of 21%, or about \u00a319 per year. {"uri": "8220272719", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "10:41:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T10:41:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T10:40:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/11/why-are-water-bills-going-up-so-much-and-what-does-it-mean-for-consumers/", "title": "Why are water bills going up so much, and what does it mean for consumers?", "body": "After Ofwat's ruling on bills, the PA news agency looks at why people are so angry with water suppliers, and what happens next.\n\nHousehold water bills in England and Wales are to rise by an average \u00a319 a year over the next five years, under draft plans announced by regulators.\n\nWhile the increase is a third less than water companies had asked for, it has sparked anger from consumer groups, after many firms' dire records on sewage spills and water leaks.\n\nMeanwhile, Environment Secretary Steve Reed promised steps towards \"ending the crisis in the water sector\", including so-called customer panels to \"hold (bosses) to account\".\n\nHere the PA news agency breaks down what happens next, and what it will mean for consumers.\n\n- What happened?\n\nEvery five years, England and Wales' regional water suppliers must submit their business plans to regulator Ofwat for the upcoming half decade.\n\nCompanies had asked for bill increases ranging from 13% over the five years to 73%. Thames Water, the country's largest water company, asked for a 44% increase.\n\nOfwat published its initial draft ruling on the plans on Thursday. Most firms were told they would not be allowed to raise bills by as much as they asked.\n\nThe average rise proposed by Ofwat is 21%, about a third less than the average increase requested by companies.\n\n- What's the damage?\n\nWater firms wanted to raise bills by \u00a3144 on average over the next five years, but Ofwat has cut that.\n\nFor example, Thames Water planned a rise of \u00a3191 by 2030, but that has been reduced to \u00a399.\n\nThere are significant variations in price changes between firms.\n\nUnder the plans, Southern Water customers will face a \u00a3183 increase over five years, while Dwr Cymru customers' bills will go up by \u00a3137.\n\nAt the other end of the scale, Affinity customers will see just an \u00a311 rise, while SES customers' bills will fall by \u00a334 on the previous five years.\n\n- Why do they want to raise bills so much?\n\nWater firms face serious problems with their drains, reservoirs and sewers, leading to vast amounts of pollution spilling into rivers and waterways.\n\nThat means firms need to spend billions on upgrading their systems, as well as turn a profit so they can keep getting more investment from shareholders.\n\nTo make matters worse, many face huge debt piles. The 10 biggest water companies have about \u00a360 billion of combined debt.\n\nMike Keil, chief executive of the Consumer Council for Water (CCW), said: \"Millions of people will feel upset and anxious at the prospect of these water bill rises and question the fairness of them given some water companies' track record of failure and poor service.\"\n\n- Why are people angry?\n\nCritics say firms have chronically underinvested in their infrastructure since they were privatised in 1989, while paying out huge shareholder dividends.\n\nIn the 30 years since water firms moved into private hands, not a single major reservoir has been built in England and Wales.\n\nSarah Bentley, Thames Water's previous chief executive, admitted before she resigned that it had been \"hollowed out\" by \"decades of underinvestment\".\n\nNew rules were introduced last year to ensure that water companies do not pay dividends unless they are judged to have delivered for customers and the environment.\n\nMr Keil continued: \"Trust in water companies has never been lower and that won't change until people see and experience a difference, whether that's having the confidence to swim at their favourite beach or receiving help if they are struggling to pay their bill.\"\n\n- Is anyone trying to fix it?\n\nChancellor Rachel Reeves said the Government will \"get a grip\" on the sector.\n\nMr Reed said he would meet representatives from all 16 water companies from across England and Wales on Thursday.\n\nHe said he has written to Ofwat to ask them to make sure funding for vital infrastructure investment is ringfenced and can only be spent on upgrades benefiting customers and the environment.\n\nHe also said that consumers will gain \"new powers to hold water company bosses to account\" through so-called customer panels.\n\nHe said: \"This unacceptable destruction of our waterways should never have been allowed, but change has now begun so it can never happen again.\"\n\n- What happens next?\n\nOfwat's ruling is only a draft decision, and begins a period of negotiation until its final verdict in December.\n\nBut the regulator has rarely made major deviations from its draft and final rulings in previous years.\n\nThat means Thursday's statement gives all parties a rough indication of what the final decision on bills will look like.\n\nIf companies still do not accept Ofwat's final ruling in December, they can appeal to the Competition and Markets Authority.\n\nOfwat chief executive David Black said: \"Let me be very clear to water companies, we will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment {"uri": "2024-07-418685366", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "13:10:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T13:10:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T13:09:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.businessgreen.com/news/4334325/ofwat-confirms-hike-water-bills-pay-sewage-spill-crackdown", "title": "Ofwat confirms hike in water bills to pay for sewage spill crackdown", "body": "Regulator sets out controversial plan to triple water sector's investment in environment and customer service, but water firms argue proposed bill hike will not be enough to deliver required infrastructure improvements\n\nWater bills in England and Wales will rise by an average of \u00a394 over the next five years as part of a broader investment programme to tackle the UK's sewage crisis, according to plans set out by the water regulator this morning.\n\nUnder the new draft proposals, Ofwat said it would approve an increase to water bills of an average of \u00a319 per year over the next five years, and that any funds found to have not been spent on investment in improving water infrastructure would be returned to customers.\n\nThe plan set out regulator today would put the water industry on a path to investing \u00a388bn to deliver cleaner rivers and seas and better services to customers over the five-year period between 2025 and 2030, it said.\n\nHowever, any hike in consumer bills to pay for increased investment in water infrastructure is likely to be controversial, particularly with households continuing to grapple with an acute cost of living crisis.\n\nThe water industry has faced widespread criticism over the poor state of UK rivers and lakes, with raw sewage frequently found to have been pumped into waterways by operators across the country. They have also faced criticism for handing out billions of pounds in shareholder dividends and bonuses for bosses over recent decades, while also overseeing a dearth of investment in upgrades to water and sewage infrastructure.\n\nOfwat said its proposals unveiled today would result in a three-fold increase in investment in customer service and environmental upgrades by the water industry, compared to the previous five-year price review period.\n\nUnder the regulator's proposals, companies would be expected to invest \u00a310bn to tackle storm overflows, with a target to reduce sewage spills by 44 per cent on levels recorded in 2021.\n\nThey would also be expected to deliver \u00a317bn of new water assets, including plans for nine new reservoirs to boost the sector's resilience to climate change and ensure security of water supply. No new reservoirs have been built in the UK since 1990, despite population growth and increasing pressure on water resources from worsening climate change.\n\nDavid Black, chief executive of Ofwat, said the price review marked a major step up in investment by the water sector, and would also help the sector prepare for the escalating impacts of climate change on water resources. \"Customers want to see radical change in the way water companies care for the environment,\" he said. \"Our draft decisions on company plans approve a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer service and the environment at a fair price for customers.\n\n\"Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for nine reservoirs.\"\n\nHowever, Ofwat has approved only a third of the increases in consumer bills requested by water companies in submissions to the regulator last October, which has stoked criticism from the industry today. Water firms had argued greater increases in bills were needed to bolster Britain's creaking water infrastructure.\n\nIn their initial submissions to Ofwat, water companies proposed increasing their expenditure over the period between 2025 and 2030 to \u00a329bn, with \u00a35bn set aside for business operations and \u00a324bn for environmental improvements.\n\nBut after scrutinising these proposals, Ofwat has agreed to allow firms to only raise a further \u00a316bn through bills, arguing much of the additional expenditure requested by water companies had been \"insufficiently justified, inefficient or for activity companies had already funded\".\n\nThe water regulator has also attached a \"claw back guarantee\" to all investment which would ensure money not spent by water companies on upgrades would be returned to customers, Ofwat said.\n\nThe measure comes after Environment Secretary Steve Reed wrote to Ofwat to demand that infrastructure investment by water companies was \"ringfenced\" and could only be spent in upgrades benefiting customers and the environment.\n\nBlack said it would now be \"closely scrutinising\" water company delivery plans in order to \"hold [firms] to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes\".\n\nAlan Lovell, chair of the Environment Agency, said Ofwat's investment plan marked \"a significant step forward in delivering the investment needed to protect rivers and seas, boost water supplies and improve resilience to flooding\".\n\n\"It will deliver four times more investment in clean and plentiful water than the previous five-year period,\" he said. \"The critical issue now is delivery.\"\n\nHowever, trade body Water UK slammed Ofwat's proposals today for failing to allow firms to raise enough funding to support requisite upgrades to infrastructure, arguing they risked undermining efforts to stop sewage spills into the UK's waterways.\n\nUnder Ofwat's plans, Thames Water's request for an increase of \u00a3191 to customer bills by 2030 has been reduced to \u00a399 and Severn Trent's proposed increase of \u00a3144 has been reduced to \u00a393, for example.\n\n\"Today's announcement is the biggest ever cut in investment by Ofwat,\" a Water UK spokesperson said. \"If it doesn't put this right Ofwat will be repeating the mistakes of the past. As a direct result, more housing will be blocked, the recovery of our rivers will be slower, and we will fail to deal with the water shortages we know are coming.\n\n\"Water companies proposed to invest \u00a3105bn because it is the minimum needed to meet the legitimate concerns we've heard from the public about our environment and our economy.\"\n\nThe price review came as the new Labour government today announced a series of new measures to crackdown on sewage spills and ramp up investment in environmental improvements.\n\nUnder the changes announced by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) this morning, citizens are to be given new powers to hold water company bosses to account through \"customer panels\" which would be able to summon water company board members.\n\nDefra has also said it plans to double the amount of compensation customers are legally entitled to when key standards are not met, with payments set to be triggered by a wider set of circumstances including boil water notices.\n\nIn a meeting with water company bosses this morning, Environment Secretary Steve Reed said he expected them to change their \"articles of association\" to make the interests of customers and the environment \"a primary objective\".\n\n\"We will never look the other way while water companies pump sewage into our rivers, lakes and seas,\" Reed said. \"This unacceptable destruction of our waterways should never have been allowed, but change has now begun so it can never happen again.\"\n\nHe added that the government would outline further steps to reform the water sector and protect waterways \"over the coming weeks and months\" noting that \"change will take time\".\n\nReed said the rise in water bills confirmed by Ofwat today were \"the result of years of failure\".\n\n\"The new government will force water companies to tackle illegal sewage dumping into our rivers, lakes and seas,\" he said. \"Firm action should have been taken much earlier to ensure money was spent on fixing the sewage system, not syphoned off for bonuses and dividends.\u202f\u202fThe decisive steps set out today mean this will never be allowed to happen again.\n\n\"After meetings with water bosses this afternoon, they have now signed up to my initial package of reforms as we work towards cleaning up our water, prioritising the interests of water customers and the environment, and fixing our broken sewage system.\"\n\nEnvironmental groups today welcomed the government's decision to intervene in the sector, arguing that Ofwat's latest proposals did not go far enough to force water companies to protect customers or tackle the sewage crisis.\n\n\"While Ofwat still seem to be trying to strike a balance between cooperating with blackmail and not triggering significant change, it's encouraging to see the government stepping into the fray and acknowledging that political choices need making as well as the need to hold water companies to account,\" said Greenpeace policy director Dr Doug Parr.\n\n\"It's now glaringly obvious that these water firms will continue to demand dividends and bonuses for continuing to not do their job for as long as they are allowed to do so. The regulator can't solve this without full government backing for a more interventionist approach, and so while Labour are right to promise a clampdown on profiteering, if they want to deliver real change in the sector and rein in serial polluters, they need to go further.\"\n\nPaul De Zlyva, senior sustainability analyst at Friends of the Earth, said the price hikes proposed by Ofwat were \"considerable\" and would be met by resistance by the public given low regard for water companies.\n\n\"People are willing to pay for essential bill rises when they get good service and real action to prevent pollution, but not to reward ongoing failure,\" he said. \"It's good to hear the new Environment Secretary Steve Reed saying he'll \"never look the other way\" and make changes in water company governance, but tough talk won't wash without greater funding for the Environment Agency and putting a Green Duty on Ofwat alongside its economic focus,\" he said. \"It's now up to the new government to set a better standard by imposing tougher sanctions on irresponsible water companies and enshrining the right to a healthy environment law.\"\n\nYou can now sign up to attend the fifth
