Thames Water, the country's largest water company, asked for a 44% increase.\n\nOfwat published its initial draft ruling on the plans on Thursday. Most firms were told they would not be allowed to raise bills by as much as they asked.\n\nThe average rise proposed by Ofwat is 21%, about a third less than the average increase requested by companies.\n\n- What's the damage?\n\nWater firms wanted to raise bills by \u00a3144 on average over the next five years, but Ofwat has cut that.\n\nFor example, Thames Water planned a rise of \u00a3191 by 2030, but that has been reduced to \u00a399.\n\nThere are significant variations in price changes between firms.\n\nUnder the plans, Southern Water customers will face a \u00a3183 increase over five years, while Dwr Cymru customers' bills will go up by \u00a3137.\n\nAt the other end of the scale, Affinity customers will see just an \u00a311 rise, while SES customers' bills will fall by \u00a334 on the previous five years.\n\n- Why do they want to raise bills so much?\n\nWater firms face serious problems with their drains, reservoirs and sewers, leading to vast amounts of pollution spilling into rivers and waterways.\n\nThat means firms need to spend billions on upgrading their systems, as well as turn a profit so they can keep getting more investment from shareholders.\n\nTo make matters worse, many face huge debt piles. The 10 biggest water companies have about \u00a360 billion of combined debt.\n\nMike Keil, chief executive of the Consumer Council for Water (CCW), said: \"Millions of people will feel upset and anxious at the prospect of these water bill rises and question the fairness of them given some water companies' track record of failure and poor service.\"\n\n- Why are people angry?\n\nCritics say firms have chronically underinvested in their infrastructure since they were privatised in 1989, while paying out huge shareholder dividends.\n\nIn the 30 years since water firms moved into private hands, not a single major reservoir has been built in England and Wales.\n\nSarah Bentley, Thames Water's previous chief executive, admitted before she resigned that it had been \"hollowed out\" by \"decades of underinvestment\".\n\nNew rules were introduced last year to ensure that water companies do not pay dividends unless they are judged to have delivered for customers and the environment.\n\nMr Keil continued: \"Trust in water companies has never been lower and that won't change until people see and experience a difference, whether that's having the confidence to swim at their favourite beach or receiving help if they are struggling to pay their bill.\"\n\n- Is anyone trying to fix it?\n\nChancellor Rachel Reeves said the Government will \"get a grip\" on the sector.\n\nMr Reed said he would meet representatives from all 16 water companies from across England and Wales on Thursday.\n\nHe said he has written to Ofwat to ask them to make sure funding for vital infrastructure investment is ringfenced and can only be spent on upgrades benefiting customers and the environment.\n\nHe also said that consumers will gain \"new powers to hold water company bosses to account\" through so-called customer panels.\n\nHe said: \"This unacceptable destruction of our waterways should never have been allowed, but change has now begun so it can never happen again.\"\n\n- What happens next?\n\nOfwat's ruling is only a draft decision, and begins a period of negotiation until its final verdict in December.\n\nBut the regulator has rarely made major deviations from its draft and final rulings in previous years.\n\nThat means Thursday's statement gives all parties a rough indication of what the final decision on bills will look like.\n\nIf companies still do not accept Ofwat's final ruling in December, they can appeal to the Competition and Markets Authority.\n\nOfwat chief executive David Black said: \"Let me be very clear to water companies, we will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment bill rises, regulator says", "body": "LONDON (Reuters) - British regulator Ofwat told water companies on Thursday that they must make environmental upgrades without raising bills as much as they had wanted amid a funding crisis and public anger over the level of pollution in rivers and the sea.\n\nThe trade-off between price hikes, private investment and cleaner rivers is a test for the new Labour government, as the biggest supplier Thames Water teeters on the brink of financial collapse.\n\nOver the next five years, Ofwat said it would allow companies to increase average bills by 21%, or 94 pounds ($121), and that they should spend 88 billion pounds on upgrading infrastructure to clean up rivers.\n\nThe companies had wanted to increase bills by an average of 33%, and invest 105 billion pounds to upgrade aging pipes and accommodate a growing UK population.\n\nThere has been a public outcry about sewage discharges into rivers and the sea, with critics saying the companies have under-invested for decades while taking out billions of pounds in dividends and paying large bonuses to executives.\n\n'MINIMUM ASK ON CUSTOMERS'\n\nOfwat's Chief Executive David Black told Times Radio: \"We do need to see real action, sustained improvements on sewage discharges, but it does need to be done in a way that puts the minimum ask on customers that's possible.\"\n\nIndustry body Water UK slammed Ofwat's proposals, accusing the regulator of prolonging a crisis which has meant crumbling pipes and more frequent sewage spills.\n\n\"For far too long, Ofwat has failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed and what it will take to deliver and maintain necessary infrastructure,\" a spokesperson said.\n\nThames Water, at the forefront of public debate about a water industry which was privatised in 1989, wanted to hike bills by a total of 191 pounds over five years, but Ofwat said it would allow a rise of 99 pounds.\n\nStruggling under 15 billion pounds of debt, Thames said on Tuesday it would run out of money next year if it did not raise 3.25 billion pounds of equity and that it needs the bill rises to ensure sufficient returns to attract investors.\n\nGOVERNMENT REFORM\n\nEnvironment minister Steve Reed, appointed after Britain's July 4 parliamentary election, said tighter regulation was needed. He told Ofwat to ensure funding for infrastructure investment was ringfenced and not spent on bonuses or dividends.\n\n\"Today I have announced significant steps to clean up the water industry to cut sewage pollution, protect customers and attract investment to upgrade its crumbling infrastructure,\" Reed said on Thursday.\n\nHe said the government would outline further steps in the next months to reform the water sector and restore British \"rivers, lakes and seas to good health.\"\n\nIt is a balancing act to clean up Britain's bodies of water, avoid soaring bills and keep investors onside.\n\nNew Prime Minister Keir Starmer wants to boost private investment into infrastructure, and investors will be looking at water as a test case.\n\nOfwat set the allowed rate of return paid to investors of water companies at 3.72%.\n\nUnder the regulator's proposals, Black told BBC radio Thames Water would be able to attract investment and \"it's now their job to go to investors and to seek to raise that funding.\"\n\nHours before Ofwat's announcement, credit rating firm S&P Global warned it could downgrade Thames' Class A and B debt to 'junk' ratings, making them uninvestible for big pension funds.\n\nOfwat is due to publish its final decision on future bills and investment on Dec. 19. We will get a grip of that.\"\n\nThe regulator said water firms had proposed increases averaging \u00a3144 over five years.\n\nFor example, Thames Water's planned rise of \u00a3191 by 2030 has been reduced to \u00a399, while Severn Trent's proposed increase of \u00a3144 has been cut to \u00a393.\n\nThere are significant variations in price changes between suppliers.\n\nUnder the plans, Southern Water customers will face a \u00a3183 increase over five years, while Dwr Cymru customers' bills will go up by \u00a3137 and Yorkshire Water customers will pay \u00a3107 more.\n\nAt the other end of the scale, Affinity customers will see just an \u00a311 rise, while SES customers' bills will fall by \u00a334 on the previous five years.\n\n\"These proposals aim to deliver a 44% reduction in spills from storm overflows compared to levels in 2021. We expect all companies to embrace innovation and go further and faster to reduce spills wherever possible.\n\n\"Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for nine reservoirs.\n\n\"Let me be very clear to water companies - we will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes.\"\n\nA Water UK spokesman said: \"Today's announcement is the biggest ever cut in investment by Ofwat. If it doesn't put this right Ofwat will be repeating the mistakes of the past. As a direct result, more housing will be blocked, the recovery of our rivers will be slower and we will fail to deal with the water shortages we know are coming.\n\n\"Water companies proposed to invest \u00a3105 billion because it is the minimum needed to meet the legitimate concerns we've heard from the public about our environment and our economy.\n\n\"Ofwat is right to want to ensure customers receive value for money and that is why protections are in place to ensure customers only pay for projects that are new, necessary and value for money.\n\n\"But for far too long Ofwat has failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed and what it will take to deliver and maintain necessary infrastructure. Ofwat now needs to let them get on with it.\"\n\n\"Customers understand investment is urgently needed but they need reassurance that every pound of their money is going to be well spent.\n\n\"Trust in water companies has never been lower and that won't change until people see and experience a difference - whether that's having the confidence to swim at their favourite beach or receiving help if they are struggling to pay their bill.\n\n\"We estimate about two million households in England and Wales currently cannot afford their water bill and, while the increase in financial assistance is welcome, it falls short of what is needed.\n\n\"Over the summer we'll be carrying out research with customers of every water company to gauge whether they feel the regulator's proposals are affordable and deliver what people want. \u00a35 billion increase in the core costs for running their business and a \u00a324 billion rise in spending to meet requirements set by governments and for other environmental improvements.\n\nOfwat polluting of waterways with sewage spills as they continue to hand dividends to shareholders, and bonuses to executives - something which Labour has pledged to clamp down on.\n\nSewage spills into {"uri": "2024-07-417672185", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:06:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:06:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:00:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/customers-refunds-waters-firms-sewage-spills-3161952", "title": "Customers to get refunds from water firms that don't tackle sewage spills", "body": "Environment Secretary Steve Reed is making his first intervention on Britain's sewage crisis since Labour won power\n\nWater companies will be forced to return money that isn't spent on upgrading their sewerage networks to customers under new plans being unveiled by the Government, can reveal.\n\nIn his first intervention on Britain's sewage crisis, Environment Secretary Steve Reed said water companies will no longer be allowed to divert infrastructure funding to pay for bonuses, dividends or salary increases.\n\nHe also revealed plans to double the compensation households receive when their water supply is disrupted and to set up new panels for customers to hold the utility firms to account.\n\n\"We will never look the other way while water companies pump sewage into our rivers, lakes and seas,\" Mr Reed said.\n\n\"This unacceptable destruction of our waterways should never have been allowed, but change has now begun so it can never happen again.\"\n\nCampaigners are likely to welcome the early intervention from Labour during the party's first week in power.\n\nHowever, it remains unclear when the new Government plans to set in motion some of the other proposals in its manifesto to clean up the UK's waterways, including prosecutions for water bosses and automatic fines for firms.\n\nLabour is also yet to commit to all the policies outlined in 's manifesto to Save Britain's Rivers and waterways, including increased funding for the Environment Agency and for farmers so they can reduce agricultural pollution, plus a \"green duty\" on regulator Ofwat to place greater emphasis on the environment when making decisions over water companies' business plans.\n\nTomorrow afternoon, Mr Reed will hold a meeting with water company chief executives to set out his plans for the sector, which has faced intense scrutiny for the dumping of sewage into Britain's rivers.\n\nThe meeting will take place on the same day that the sector's economic regulator, Ofwat, publishes its highly-anticipated decision on water companies' business plans for the next five years.\n\nThe draft decision will set out how much water companies will be allowed to increase customer bills by to pay for the upgrades needed to reduce sewage pollution.\n\nFirms have proposed bill hikes between 24 and 91 per cent over the five-year period, meaning households would be paying up to \u00a3915 per year for water by 2030.\n\nTomorrow morning, regulator Ofwat will publish its draft decision on whether to approve the business plans submitted by water companies.\n\nThese plans set out how much firms propose to spend on their infrastructure from 2025 to 2030, and how much they plan to increase bills by to fund it.\n\nIn response to public outrage over sewage spills, water companies have proposed a record investment of \u00a396 billion in their infrastructure over the five-year period.\n\nOfwat's draft decision will be the first indication of how much the regulator will allow bills to rise by to meet targets on sewage spills. Water companies will respond to the decision and a final ruling will be made by the regulator in December, with the new bills to kick in in April next year.\n\nCampaign groups have expressed fury at the prospect of huge bill hikes for customers and said Ofwat should force companies and their investors to pay for upgrades.\n\nBut Ofwat faces a standoff with investors over the bill hikes. In March, Thames Water's investors pulled the plug on \u00a3500m of emergency funding as it argued the regulator was making the firm \"uninvestable\".\n\nMr Reed has outlined four policies the Government would introduce \"to clean up the water industry to cut sewage pollution, protect customers and attract investment to upgrade its crumbling infrastructure\".\n\nThis includes plans to write to Ofwat to ask them to make sure funding for infrastructure investment is ring fenced and cannot be spent on bonuses, dividends or salary increases. This will include infrastructure investments to prevent sewage spills, among other things.\n\nAny promised infrastructure funding that is not spent on upgrades should be refunded to customers, he said.\n\nWater companies have been heavily criticised in the past for failing to spend money on their infrastructure, while paying large dividends to their investors.\n\nIn its most recent performance report for the sector, Ofwat found water companies had failed to spend \u00a3587m set aside for improving their assets between 2020 to 2023.\n\nMeanwhile, water companies in England paid \u00a32.5bn in dividends in the two financial years since 2021, analysis by the Financial Times found.\n\nWater companies are already forced to return money to customers if they fail to meet separate targets related to things such as environmental performance and leakages.\n\nLast year, 11 of the 16 water companies in England and Wales were forced to give money back to customers. This is done via deductions to bills in the following year rather than cash back.\n\nHowever, water bills have continued to rise despite firms being penalised, for example in the 2023/4 financial year, bills increased by an average of 7.5 per cent despite water companies being penalised for missing targets.\n\nIt is understood that it will be up to Ofwat to decide how exactly customers will be refunded if water companies do not spend their allocated infrastructure funding. Ofwat is an independent body but takes policy direction from ministers within the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs.\n\nAlongside restricting infrastructure spending, the Government will consult on doubling the amount of compensation customers will receive when their basic water services are affected. Depending on the circumstances, customers are typically entitled to \u00a320 in compensation if their water supply is disrupted for 24 hours, followed by \u00a310 for each additional day.\n\nMinisters will also look to expand the circumstances under which customers receive compensation to include 'Boil Water Notices', which are issued when there are contamination concerns over drinking water in a region.\n\nThe move is likely in response to the recent parasite outbreak in Devon that saw over 100 people reporting a diarrhoea-type illness and around 16,000 homes and businesses being ordered to boil their water, with some homes affected for almost two months. South West Water was forced to pay out around \u00a33.5million to affected customers.\n\nMr Reed will also order water companies to change their governing rules to make the interests of customers and the environment a primary objective.\n\nNew customer panels will be introduced with the power to summon board members and hold water executives to account, the Secretary of State said.\n\nHowever, Mr Reed stressed that change will \"take time\" to improve Britain's waterways and said the Government will outline further steps over \"the coming weeks and months\".\n\nIt's currently unclear when Labour will set in motion the other policies in its manifesto, including bringing criminal charges against water executives that break the law and introducing automatic and severe fines for polluting firms.\n\nIt is possible that more detail will be provided in the King's Speech, which is scheduled for next week.\n\nWhile Labour's proposals are likely to be welcomed by campaigners, the Government is yet to commit to some of the other changes groups have been calling for to end the sewage crisis and restore our waterways.\n\nDuring the general election campaign, published a manifesto, backed by over 20 leading environmental groups, that set out five key pledges the new Government must commit to to Save Britain's Rivers.\n\nWhile Labour has committed to some of these policies, it is yet to commit to wider changes, including more drastic reform of the regulatory system and a boost in funding for the Environment Agency, which polices sewage spills. It's also unclear how farmers will be funded to help them manage their land in a nature-friendly manner.\n\nWhat says: Within its first six months in power, the next government must publish a roadmap on how the UK is going to achieve its legal target of 77 per cent of rivers being in good ecological health by 2027. This must include increased funding for the Environment Agency.\n\nWhat Labour says: Labour's manifesto contains no mention of the legal target or of increased funding for the Environment Agency.\n\nWhat says: Untreated sewage will not cause damage to high-priority sites (which are\u202fbathing spots, protected nature sites, National Parks and chalk streams) by 2030. Water companies who fail to meet this target will be prosecuted.\n\nWhat Labour says: Labour has said it will pursue criminal charges against the executives of water companies responsible for persistent pollution, but currently has no plans to toughen sewage spill targets beyond what has been set by the current government. Water companies will be forced to amend their governing rules to make the interests of customers and the environment a primary objective.\n\nWhat says: The next government must publish a plan to reform the regulation of water companies, including tougher powers for Ofwat to restrict dividends and bonuses for underperforming water companies. A \"green duty\" will be placed on Ofwat, which will force the regulator to place greater emphasis on the environment when making decisions over water companies' business plans.\n\nWhat Labour says: The party will give regulators new powers to block the payment of bonuses and bring criminal charges against executives who pollute waterways and will impose automatic and severe fines for wrongdoing. Ofwat will also be asked to ensure customers are refunded if infrastructure money is not spent so that it cannot be diverted to pay for bonuses or dividends. Labour has not committed to a 'green duty' for Ofwat.\n\nWhat says: 100 clean bathing spots must be created in England by the end of the parliament and the Environment Agency must start monitoring water quality throughout the year at these sites.\n\nWhat Labour says: The party has made no reference to bathing spots in its manifesto.\n\nWhat says: Within its first year in power, the next government will strengthen its Environmental Land Management scheme so farmers are given more grants, support and advice to undertake activities that will improve water quality.\n\nWhat Labour says: Labour says it will ensure \"environment land management schemes work for farmers and nature\", but is yet to provide more detail on what that will entail. British regulator Ofwat told water companies on Thursday that they must make environmental upgrades without raising bills as much as they had wanted amid a funding crisis and public anger over the level of pollution in rivers and the sea.\n\nThe trade-off between price hikes, private investment and cleaner rivers is a test for the new Labour government, as the biggest supplier Thames Water teeters on the brink of financial collapse.\n\nOver the next five years, Ofwat said it would allow companies to increase average bills by 21%, or 94 pounds ($121), and that they should spend 88 billion pounds on upgrading infrastructure to clean up rivers.\n\nThe companies had wanted to increase bills by an average of 33%, and invest 105 billion pounds to upgrade aging pipes and accommodate a growing UK population.\n\nThere has been a public outcry about sewage discharges into rivers and the sea, with critics saying the companies have under-invested for decades while taking out billions of pounds in dividends and paying large bonuses to executives.\n\n'MINIMUM ASK ON CUSTOMERS'\n\nOfwat's Chief Executive David Black told Times Radio: \"We do need to see real action, sustained improvements on sewage discharges, but it does need to be done in a way that puts the minimum ask on customers that's possible.\"\n\nIndustry body Water UK slammed Ofwat's proposals, accusing the regulator of prolonging a crisis which has meant crumbling pipes and more frequent sewage spills.\n\n\"For far too long, Ofwat has failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed and what it will take to deliver and maintain necessary infrastructure,\" a spokesperson said.\n\nThames Water, at the forefront of public debate about a water industry which was privatised in 1989, wanted to hike bills by a total of 191 pounds over five years, but Ofwat said it would allow a rise of 99 pounds.\n\nStruggling under 15 billion pounds of debt, Thames said on Tuesday it would run out of money next year if it did not raise 3.25 billion pounds of equity and that it needs the bill rises to ensure sufficient returns to attract investors.\n\nGOVERNMENT REFORM\n\nEnvironment minister Steve Reed, appointed after Britain's July 4 parliamentary election, said tighter regulation was needed. He told Ofwat to ensure funding for infrastructure investment was ringfenced and not spent on bonuses or dividends.\n\n\"Today I have announced significant steps to clean up the water industry to cut sewage pollution, protect customers and attract investment to upgrade its crumbling infrastructure,\" Reed said on Thursday.\n\nHe said the government would outline further steps in the next months to reform the water sector and restore British \"rivers, lakes and seas to good health.\"\n\nIt is a balancing act to clean up Britain's bodies of water, avoid soaring bills and keep investors onside.\n\nNew Prime Minister Keir Starmer wants to boost private investment into infrastructure, and investors will be looking at water as a test case.\n\nOfwat set the allowed rate of return paid to investors of water companies at 3.72%.\n\nUnder the regulator's proposals, Black told BBC radio Thames Water would be able to attract investment and \"it's now their job to go to investors and to seek to raise that funding.\"\n\nHours before Ofwat's announcement, credit rating firm S&amp;P Global warned it could downgrade Thames' Class A and B debt to 'junk' ratings, making them uninvestible for big pension funds.\n\nOfwat is due to publish its final decision on future bills and investment on Dec. 19. (Reuters) - Britain's under-fire water companies are braced for a reckoning when the industry's regulator on Thursday sets out the level of bill increases they will be permitted, amid public outrage over rising costs and worsening pollution.\n\nThe trade-off between price hikes, investment and the environment will test the country's new Labour government, and will illustrate the challenges of managing the privatised water industry, particularly as Thames Water- the biggest supplier - teeters on the brink of collapse.\n\nWater companies have routinely released sewage into rivers and seas, which have made Britain's waters increasingly dirty in the last five years, putting the regulator, Ofwat, under intense pressure to act.\n\nIt will publish its initial decision on how much the dozen or so water companies can charge customers for the 2025-2030 period before a final decision in December.\n\nOfwat said Thames has asked for a 44% increase in bills over the period, excluding inflation, while other providers have sought varying amounts, from Southern Water's 73% hike to Severn Trent's 36% rise and United Utilities' 25% rise.\n\nThe companies say the bill hikes are needed to upgrade ageing pipe networks and help accommodate a growing UK population, and say more frequent droughts and storms have helped cause sewage spills.\n\nBut critics of the industry, privatised in 1989, argue that the companies have under-invested for decades while taking out billions of pounds in dividends for shareholders and paying large bonuses to executives.\n\n\"We want the water bill payer protected and for essential infrastructure funding to come from investors and lenders who have, until now, profited from pollution,\" James Wallace, CEO of environmental group River Action UK, said in an emailed response to a Reuters request for comment.\n\nTOUGH LINE\n\nWhile the government might publicly want the regulator to take a tough line on the water companies, it also needs investors onside as newly elected Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks tens of billions of pounds of private investment to upgrade infrastructure and revive Britain's economic growth.\n\nThe new government is setting up a National Wealth Fund which wants to attract private investment, to the tune of three pounds of private money for every pound from public funds, for clean energy and other projects.\n\nThames Water, which supplies a quarter of Britain's population, has a 15 billion pound ($19 billion) debt pile and is at risk of collapse next year unless it can convince reluctant shareholders, bond investors plus new investors to stump up more cash.\n\n\"Thames is a high profile asset and if Thames isn't dealt with carefully then that could influence investor sentiment,\" said Nalaka De Silva, head of private market solutions at fund manager abrdn.\n\n\"What they need to do is basically convey a message that the policy and regulatory environment is stable.\"\n\nA Thames collapse could spook investors in the water sector as well as further afield in regulated sectors like energy where Britain also needs investment.\n\nIn 2019, Ofwat agreed a plan for average water bills to fall by 12% before inflation over the five years.\n\nBut since then, both inflation and interest rates have jumped, making price rises in the next period all but inevitable to allow investors to make returns.\n\nA number of major international funds have already sold out of Thames bonds in recent months, filings data shows, after its parent company Kemble Water defaulted in April amid a standoff with shareholders over providing more equity.\n\nSome investors blame Ofwat for allowing the crisis at Thames to develop.\n\n\"It completely degrades the whole system of regulation,\" said one major investor who asked to remain anonymous having recently sold out of Thames. \"It has left a very sour taste\".\n\n($1 = 0.7814 pounds)\n\n(Reporting by Sarah Young and Marc Jones; Editing by Mr Reed will then meet executives in Whitehall to lay out his plans.\n\nThe amount of compensation to be paid to customers for water outages and other problems will be doubled to around \u00a350 under the proposals. The trigger for compensation will also be widened to include so-called \"boil notices\" when water is unsafe to drink.\n\nNew \"customer panels\" will be rolled out to help bill payers hold company bosses to account, and companies will be forced to change their articles of association to make the interests of customers and the environment a primary objective.\n\nMr Reed said: \"We will never look the other way while water companies pump sewage into our rivers, lakes and seas.\n\n\"This unacceptable destruction of our waterways should never have been allowed, but change has now begun so it can never happen again.\n\n\"Today I have announced significant steps to clean up the water industry, to cut sewage pollution, protect customers and attract investment to upgrade its crumbling infrastructure.\n\n\"That change will take time. We expect all companies to embrace innovation and go further and faster to reduce spills wherever possible.\n\n\"Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for nine reservoirs.\n\n\"Let me be very clear to water companies - we will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes.\"\n\nMike Keil, chief executive of the Consumer Council for Water (CCW), said: \"Millions of people will feel upset and anxious at the prospect of these water bill rises and question the fairness of them given some water companies' track record of failure and poor service.\n\n\"Customers understand investment is urgently needed but they need reassurance that every pound of their money is going to be well spent.\n\n\"Trust in water companies has never been lower and that won't change until people see and experience a difference - whether that's having the confidence to swim at their favourite beach or receiving help if they are struggling to pay their bill.\n\n\"We estimate about two million households in England and Wales currently cannot afford their water bill and, while the increase in financial assistance is welcome, it falls short of what is needed.\n\n\"Over the summer we'll be carrying out research with customers of every water company to gauge whether they feel the regulator's proposals are affordable and deliver what people want. Investors earlier this year pulled the plug on \u00a3500m of emergency funding, with the company's largest shareholder - a Canadian pension fund - later writing down the value of its stake to zero.\n\nWhitehall officials are understood to have briefed Prime Minister Keir Starmer and Chancellor Rachel Reeves within hours of their election victory last week that the plight of Thames Water represents a \"critical risk\" to the country and is one of the most urgent problems facing the new Labour government.\n\nChris Weston, a former British Gas executive who was brought in as the latest chief executive at Thames Water in January, warned that the utility only has enough money to fund its operations until next May and urged Ofwat to take steps to make the company \"investable\" for the private sector.\n\nThe industry regulator will announce on Thursday whether it will allow Thames Water to proceed with a five-year business plan which promises a renewed investment programme in return for raising average household bills by 59 per cent between 2025 and 2030. Such an increase would represent an average annual bill of \u00a3759 for each of Thames's 16 million customers across London and the Thames Valley.\n\nAnnouncing the company's annual results, Mr Weston said: \"We are dependent on securing a final regulatory determination that is deliverable, financeable and investable, as well as affordable for our customers.\"\n\nThe plea came as it emerged that Mr Weston will take a bonus of \u00a3195,00 for his work with Thames Water until March, taking his pay for the period to \u00a3437,000. Alastair Cochran, the company's chief financial officer, received a bonus of \u00a3446,000 as part of a total remuneration of \u00a31.33m - a figure which also reflected his role as a co-CEO for part of last year.\n\nIt can be revealed by that Ofwat is examining the bonus payments to see whether they comply with new rules designed to block \"inappropriate\" pay awards. The regulator recently tightened rules on executive pay to allow it from next year to claw back bonuses which are judged to have been funded from customer revenues and made despite missed environmental or performance targets.\n\nAn Ofwat spokesperson said it was \"looking into\" the executive payments and would respond \"if necessary using our new powers to protect customers\".\n\nCampaigners reacted angrily to the latest evidence of Thames Water's struggles after the company said it had seen a six per cent rise in pollution incidents to 350 - a situation which the utility said was due to unusually heavy rainfall. The company said high rainfall was also responsible for the more-than-doubling last year of sewage discharges from its network to 16,990 from 8,015.\n\nThe utility also said it had recorded its lowest ever leakage rate of 570.4 megalitres a day, a figure which nonetheless represented the loss of the equivalent of 228 Olympic swimming pools every 24 hours or a 23 per cent loss of total daily supply.\n\nAsh Smith, of Windrush Against Sewage Pollution, told : \"Thames Water is in its precarious financial state due to the actions of a long line of overpaid CEOs who have overseen the destruction of a properly funded company that has been used as a cash machine for shareholders.\n\n\"Now the company is trying to use its debt mountain to blackmail the government into bailing it out and it wants to keep extracting cash from captive billpayers.\"\n\nPaul de Zylva, a senior analyst at Friends of the Earth, said: \"It's staggering that the company is still counting on weak regulation to allow it to survive by pushing its problems onto its customers. The regulator must end this licence for water companies to profit from pollution, while wildlife and our health is put at risk.\"\n\nIt is understood Thames Water believes the bonus payments to its senior executives are justified in order for it to attract the right personnel. The company said its bonuses were based on meeting performance goals in areas including leakages, pollution and customer complaints.\n\nMr Weston insisted that any temporary nationalisation was \"a long way off\" and was \"not in the interests in any of our stakeholders of the UK taxpayer\".\n\nHe added that company had taken \"informal soundings\" which indicated there may be interest from a \"broad church\" of new and existing investors. A blueprint codenamed Project Timber was drawn up in Whitehall in the spring, which could see the company effectively nationalised.\n\nUnder the plans, the company would be placed in a form of special administration in the scenario that its parent company fails.\n\nLabour has insisted it will put water companies under new \"special measures\" including stricter control of bonuses and automatic fines.\n\nA party source said: \"We are in this situation because of 14 years of Conservative incompetence. under-invested for decades\n\nBy Sarah Young and Marc Jones\n\nLONDON, July 10 (Reuters) - Britain's under-fire water companies are braced for a reckoning when the industry's regulator on Thursday sets out the level of bill increases they will be permitted, amid public outrage over rising costs and worsening pollution.\n\nThe trade-off between price hikes, investment and the environment will test the country's new Labour government, and will illustrate the challenges of managing the privatised water industry, particularly as Thames Water - the biggest supplier - teeters on the brink of collapse.\n\nWater companies have routinely released sewage into rivers and seas, which have made Britain's waters increasingly dirty in the last five years, putting the regulator, Ofwat, under intense pressure to act.\n\nIt will publish its initial decision on how much the dozen or so water companies can charge customers for the 2025-2030 period before a final decision in December.\n\nOfwat said Thames has asked for a 44% increase in bills over the period, excluding inflation, while other providers have sought varying amounts, from Southern Water's 73% hike to Severn Trent's 36% rise and United Utilities' 25% rise.\n\nThe companies say the bill hikes are needed to upgrade ageing pipe networks and help accommodate a growing UK population, and say more frequent droughts and storms have helped cause sewage spills.\n\nBut critics of the industry, privatised in 1989, argue that the companies have under-invested for decades while taking out billions of pounds in dividends for shareholders and paying large bonuses to executives.\n\n\"We want the water bill payer protected and for essential infrastructure funding to come from investors and lenders who have, until now, profited from pollution,\" James Wallace, CEO of environmental group River Action UK, said in an emailed response to a Reuters request for comment.\n\nTOUGH LINE\n\nWhile the government might publicly want the regulator to take a tough line on the water companies, it also needs investors onside as newly elected Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks tens of billions of pounds of private investment to upgrade infrastructure and revive Britain's economic growth.\n\nThe new government is setting up a National Wealth Fund which wants to attract private investment, to the tune of three pounds of private money for every pound from public funds, for clean energy and other projects.\n\nThames Water, which supplies a quarter of Britain's population, has a 15 billion pound ($19 billion) debt pile and is at risk of collapse next year unless it can convince reluctant shareholders, bond investors plus new investors to stump up more cash.\n\n\"Thames is a high profile asset and if Thames isn't dealt with carefully then that could influence investor sentiment,\" said Nalaka De Silva, head of private market solutions at fund manager abrdn.\n\n\"What they need to do is basically convey a message that the policy and regulatory environment is stable.\"\n\nA Thames collapse could spook investors in the water sector as well as further afield in regulated sectors like energy where Britain also needs investment.\n\nIn 2019, Ofwat agreed a plan for average water bills to fall by 12% before inflation over the five years.\n\nBut since then, both inflation and interest rates have jumped, making price rises in the next period all but inevitable to allow investors to make returns.\n\nA number of major international funds have already sold out of Thames bonds in recent months, filings data shows, after its parent company Kemble Water defaulted in April amid a standoff with shareholders over providing more equity.\n\nSome investors blame Ofwat for allowing the crisis at Thames to develop.\n\n\"It completely degrades the whole system of regulation,\" said one major investor who asked to remain anonymous having recently sold out of Thames. \"It has left a very sour taste\".\n\n($1 = 0.7814 pounds)\n\n(Reporting by Sarah Young and Marc Jones; Editing by David Holmes)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, Ofwat said that this reflected its analysis of those plans, removing or reducing costs where expenditure was insufficiently justified, inefficient or for activity for which companies have already been funded.\n\n\u00a335bn of the expenditure reflects the investment needed to reduce pollution, improve customer service, river and bathing water quality, and deliver greater resilience to the impact of climate change, it said. This is more than a trebling of the level of investment in the 2020 to 2025 period.\n\nThe water companies wanted to increased customers' bills by an average of \u00a3144 over the five years. Ofwat has reduced this to \u00a394 (\u00a319 a year), excluding inflation. Thames Water's proposed increase of \u00a3191 by 2030 has been reduced to \u00a399; Severn Trent's proposed increase of \u00a3144 has been reduced to \u00a393.\n\nThe overall investment programme is expected to reduce the number of spills from storm overflows by 44% (compared with 2021 levels) by spending \u00a310bn and upgrading 2,500 storm overflows; this includes the 21% reduction that Ofwat has required companies to deliver by 2025 at their own expense.\n\nSome \u00a36bn is to be invested in securing water supplies, including progressing nine new reservoirs and seven large-scale water transfer schemes.\n\nWater companies will be required to replace around 8,000 km of water mains pipes, a 400% increase compared with the current five-year period.\n\nThese draft decisions are open for consultation and responses are welcome from customers, stakeholders and water companies. The deadline for consultation responses is 12 noon on 28 August 2024.\n\nOfwat expects to publish its final decisions on 19 December 2024. If companies do not agree with the final decisions, they have two months from the date of publication to ask for an appeal to the Competition & Markets Authority.\n\nOfwat chief executive David Black said: \"Customers want to see radical change in the way water companies care for the environment. Our draft decisions on company plans approve a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer service and the environment at a fair price for customers.\n\n\"These proposals aim to deliver a 44% reduction in spills from storm overflows compared to levels in 2021. We expect all companies to embrace innovation and go further and faster to reduce spills wherever possible.\n\n\"Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for nine reservoirs.\n\n\"Let me be very clear to water companies. We will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes.\"\n\nCoinciding with Ofwat's draft determination, the new secretary of state for environment, food and rural affairs, Steve Reed, has written to the regulator to ask it to make sure that infrastructure funding is ringfenced and can only be spent on upgrades benefiting customers and the environment. He also wants Ofwat to ensure that when money for investment is not spent, companies refund customers, with money never allowed to be diverted for bonuses, dividends or salary increases.", "source": We will continue to work with Ofwat over the coming months to make our case again,\" he said.\n\nThe government wants Ofwat to ensure consumers get value for money. But Thames Water argues investors need to make returns in upgrading infrastructure which is more than 100 years old to cope with a growing population and climate change.\n\nThe company is struggling with 15 billion pounds ($19.21 billion) of debt. Its current owners said in March they would not provide a 500-million pound equity lifeline, calling it \"uninvestible\".\n\nThames Water said its liquidity of 1.8 billion pounds was sufficient to keep funding operations until the end of May 2025.\n\nFor the year to the end of March, it swung to a post-tax profit of 140 million pounds from a loss last year, but the number of pollution spills rose.\n\nThames Water's nine shareholders include Ontario Municipal Employees Retirement System, the UK's Universities Superannuation Scheme, a unit of the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority and the China Investment Corporation. including Windermere in the Lake District have been polluted.\n\nStorm overflows - which release untreated wastewater into rivers and seas when there is heavy rain to prevent sewers becoming overwhelmed - dumped sewage into the environment 464,056 times and for more than 3.6 million hours in 2023.\n\nWater utilities have also been hit by multimillion-pound fines for repeated and damaging illegal pollution in the last five years, and there is concern about the levels of leaks from water infrastructure - especially in times of drought when hosepipe bans are imposed.\n\nAnd worse is to come as climate change and worsening weather extremes, from downpours to drought, pile more pressure on supplies.\n\nMeanwhile, some of the privatised water companies are creaking under high levels of issued draft proposals to put up bills by \u00a319 a year on average, or \u00a394 over five years, a third less than the \u00a3144 average requested by water companies.\n\nOfwat said its proposals approved a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer services and the environment, including a 44% reduction in sewage spills from storm overflows, compared with levels in 2021, and plans for nine reservoirs to reduce water taken from rivers.\n\nBut while Water UK, which represents water companies, complained that Ofwat has \"failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed\", and urged the regulator to let them get on with an unprecedented overhaul of the country's water infrastructure, campaigners had a very different take.\n\nSewage spills from water infrastructure have contributed to a situation in which no single river in England is considered to be in good overall health, and beauty spots including Windermere in the Lake District have been polluted.\n\nStorm overflows - which release untreated wastewater into rivers and seas when there is heavy rain to prevent sewers becoming overwhelmed - dumped sewage into the environment 464,056 times and for more than 3.6 million hours in 2023.\n\nWater utilities have also been hit by multimillion-pound fines for repeated and damaging illegal pollution in the last five years, and there is concern about the levels of leaks from water infrastructure - especially in times of drought when hosepipe bans are imposed.\n\nAnd worse is to come as climate change and worsening weather extremes, from downpours to drought, pile more pressure on supplies.\n\nMeanwhile, some of the privatised water companies are creaking under high levels of debt or face criticism over dividends to shareholders and executive bonuses.\n\nReacting to the announcement by Ofwat, Giles Bristow, chief executive of Surfers Against Sewage, said: \"The General Election campaign made clear that the public is fed up with those in power turning a blind eye to the sewage scandal.\n\n\"Unfortunately today's announcement, in which Ofwat accepts that we will all have to swim and surf in sewage way beyond 2030, does nothing to change that.\n\n\"Signing off on the continuation of at least 200,000 sewage discharges a year is simply unacceptable and a sign that the regulator still doesn't comprehend the scale of public fury on this issue.\"\n\nHe called for the new Labour Government to launch a public inquiry as the only way to \"help us understand how we got here and how we can dig our way out\".\n\nPaul de Zylva, from Friends of the Earth, said the decision on bills and investment \"yet again proves that our current form of water privatisation is not fit for purpose\".\n\n\"It sees water companies pile pressure on Ofwat to allow them to hike customers' bills to subsidise long-overdue investment in our crumbling sewage infrastructure which might cut or prevent some, but by no means all, pollution.\"\n\nWhile he said Ofwat's draft determination shows it is not pandering to everything water companies want, many will still see the increase in bills as \"unfair\".\n\nHe called for the Government to provide greater funding for the Environment Agency, which is tasked with regulating the environmental actions of water companies, and put a \"green duty\" on Ofwat alongside its environmental focus, as well as impose tougher sanctions on \"irresponsible\" water firms.\n\nNew Environment Secretary Steve Reed is meeting bosses from all 16 water companies covering England and Wales on Thursday, amid the furore over bills and sewage.\n\nLabour has set out the first steps it plans to take to tackle the issue, including ring-fencing funding for infrastructure, and more power and focus on customers.\n\nTim Farron, environment spokesman for the Liberal Democrats who campaigned heavily on the sewage scandal in the election, warned that any \"insulting price hikes\" by water companies must be blocked.\n\n\"It is a national scandal that these disgraced firms are demanding more money from families and pensioners in a cost-of-living crisis, all whilst dumping raw sewage into our rivers,\" he said.\n\n\"Communities spoke loudly at the election, demanding an end to the sewage scandal and water firms stuffing their pockets with bonuses and dividends. The Government and regulator must listen to the country.\"\n\nThe Green Party has called for water companies to be taken into public ownership.\n\nGreen MP Sian Berry said: \"Once this is done, Government can invest affordably in the creaking infrastructure without all the harm falling on to our bills, and into our rivers and oceans that are currently being treated as open sewers.\"\n\nAnd chief executive of campaign group River Action James Wallace said: \"These bill hikes punish households struggling with the cost-of-living crisis for the abject failure of greedy water companies to invest in their crumbling infrastructure and reduce record sewage spills.\n\n\"For decades the industry has put profit before the environment, rewarding its shareholders with billions in dividends, and in the process filling our rivers with human sewage.\n\n\"We must fix this national embarrassment of systemic sewage pollution which has caused environmental carnage to our rivers.\"\n\nMr Wallace called for failing water companies to be put into special administration, and for Ofwat and the EA to be properly resourced and reformed to prioritise people and the environment.", "source": {"uri": "uk.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! with fury to proposed water bill increases for households amid the sewage pollution scandal and cost-of-living crisis.\n\nRegulator Ofwat has issued draft proposals to put up bills by \u00a319 a year on average, or \u00a394 over five years, a third less than the \u00a3144 average requested by water companies.\n\nOfwat said its proposals approved a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer services and the environment, including a 44% reduction in sewage spills from storm overflows, compared with levels in 2021, and plans for nine reservoirs to reduce water taken from rivers.\n\nBut while Water UK, which represents water companies, complained that Ofwat has \"failed to be realistic about the levels of investment needed\", and urged the regulator to let them get on with an unprecedented overhaul of the country's water infrastructure, campaigners had a very different take.\n\nSewage spills from water infrastructure have contributed to a situation in which no single river in England is considered to be in good overall health, and beauty spots including Windermere in the Lake District have been polluted.\n\nStorm overflows - which release untreated wastewater into rivers and seas when there is heavy rain to prevent sewers becoming overwhelmed - dumped sewage into the environment 464,056 times and for more than 3.6 million hours in 2023.\n\nWater utilities have also been hit by multimillion-pound fines for repeated and damaging illegal pollution in the last five years, and there is concern about the levels of leaks from water infrastructure - especially in times of drought when hosepipe bans are imposed.\n\nAnd worse is to come as climate change and worsening weather extremes, from downpours to drought, pile more pressure on supplies.\n\nMeanwhile, some of the privatised water companies are creaking under high levels of debt or face criticism over dividends to shareholders and executive bonuses.\n\nReacting to the the sewage scandal.\n\n\"Unfortunately today's announcement, in which Ofwat accepts that we will all have to swim and surf in sewage way beyond 2030, does nothing to change that.\n\n\"Signing off on the continuation of at least 200,000 sewage discharges a year is simply unacceptable and a sign that the regulator still doesn't comprehend the scale of public fury on this issue.\"\n\nHe called for the new Labour Government to launch a public inquiry as the only way to \"help us understand how we got here and how we can dig our way out\".\n\nPaul de Zylva, from Friends of the Earth, said the decision on bills and investment \"yet again proves that our current form of water privatisation is not fit for purpose\".\n\n\"It sees water companies pile pressure on Ofwat to allow them to hike Thames Water wants customer bills to rise by 59% after accounting for inflation. Southern is seeking to raise bills by 91% by 2030, to \u00a3915 a year.\n\nThe letter, organised by the campaign group We Own It, was also signed by the GMB and Unite unions. It says: \"Saturday marked 35 years since the Water Act 1989 established our current model of water and sewage management, including privatisation and top-down regulation.\n\n\"Bills have risen at twice the rate of inflation. No new drinking reservoirs have been delivered. A quarter of our supply leaks out of our pipes. Debts are unpaid; plans 'uninvestable'. And last year, operators released sewage for over 3 million hours into our rivers and seas.\n\n\"If the current failed model remains in place, Labour could be fighting the next election with some bills topping \u00a3915 a year and sewage a greater threat to our health than ever.\"\n\nThe letter calls on the prime minister to pause the current price-setting process and start a root-and-branch public review of ownership and regulation immediately, including consultation with water campaigners, trade union representatives and customers.\n\nWater companies are promising their biggest ever investment of \u00a3100bn to fix ageing infrastructure, cut sewage discharges and build new reservoirs, 35 years after the sector was privatised.\n\nThey are acting after a public outcry over sewage pollution in rivers and seas, and a decline in the state of English rivers to a situation in which no river is deemed to be in good health. As well as concern over river health, there are growing fears about the threat to public health from the way wastewater is treated in England. The chief medical officer for England, Prof Chris Whitty, has said public health must be central to future investment in a new wastewater system to protect people from waterborne diseases from contact with rivers and coastal waters polluted by treated and untreated sewage.\n\nThe regulator Ofwat, which is itself under pressure for allowing companies to pay dividends of \u00a378bn in the past three decades while building debts of \u00a360bn, will on Thursday announce whether it approves the business plans of the main water and sewerage companies.\n\nThe Ofwat decision, which was delayed until 11 July because of the general election, comes amid a growing crisis in the water sector. Thames Water, the biggest privatised water monopoly, is struggling to stay afloat with debts of almost \u00a315bn, and investors are threatening to pull the plug on the company. Ofwat has flagged concerns over the financial resilience of other privatised companies, including Southern Water, SES Water and South East Water, as of the highest concern. The financial resilience of Yorkshire Water and Portsmouth Water is also of concern by the regulator.\n\n\"No other country in the world runs water and sewage in the way we do: 90% is publicly owned and delivered,\" the letter to Starmer says.\n\n\"Regulation has been flawed, captured, and underfunded: a constant threat of the current model. {"uri": "8220675710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "14:49:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T14:49:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T14:47:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2024/07/11/thames-water-paying-price-years-greed-incompetence/", "title": "Thames Water is paying the price for years of greed and incompetence", "body": "The accusation so often levelled against Britain's water regulator is that it has been asleep at the wheel while the industry sinks into the seas that suppliers continue to routinely pollute.\n\nThat's not unfair. For years, Ofwat sat back and did little as the sector accumulated gargantuan debts, with the effect of turbo-boosting returns to absentee shareholders, neglecting desperately needed investment and service in the process - and polluting our waterways with abandon to boot.\n\nWith Thames Water now on the brink of collapse and public anger mounting at the situation, Ofwat appears to have woken up to the national scandal taking place before its eyes by rejecting water companies' demands for steep bill increases in an interim verdict on suppliers' five-year business plans.\n\nThat is to be applauded. If Ofwat were to emerge from these negotiations with any credibility it had to get tough, particularly given the eye-watering increases some suppliers have asked for.\n\nSouthern Water - one of the more financially stretched companies - topped the league of shame with a proposed rise of more than 90pc once inflation is taken into account between 2025 and 2030. That's equivalent to bill increases of nearly \u00a3306. Industry pariah Thames wants to ramp up bills by 56pc to nearly \u00a3627 per year.\n\nThursday's ruling will come as a severe shock to some, then, after the watchdog ruled that bills will rise by \u00a319 a year or 21pc on average by the end of the decade - a third less than the combined increases that the 16 companies had submitted.\n\nPredictably, it didn't take long for the howls of protest from suppliers to be heard. Industry lobbyist Water UK warned that Ofwat had swung too far the other way and risks killing off investment by watering down returns too heavily. Bemoaning \"the biggest ever cut in investment\", lobbyist Water UK claimed: \"If it doesn't put this right, Ofwat will be repeating the mistakes of the past.\"\n\nNonsense. It's the sort of tin-eared response that merely underlines the extent to which the industry still doesn't get it, despite the uproar at its woeful track record and the dramatic consequence of years of debt-fuelled ownership.\n\nThis is a wake-up call. Suppliers are finally paying the price for their incompetence and greed. Investors have had more than a decade of being allowed to financially engineer these businesses during which the media, campaigners, and politicians warned that the consequences would be extremely bad - but they didn't listen.\n\nIt couldn't go on forever. A system that privatises the profits during the go-go years cannot socialise the losses when the music stops. What shareholders are effectively asking the rest of us to accept is for them to have unlimited upside and for all the risk to sit with bill-payers so that they can walk away when it all goes wrong, leaving the public is left to pick up the pieces. If Ofwat hadn't got tough then there was a real risk of it creating moral hazard.\n\nIn making an example of Thames, the chances of that happening are dramatically reduced. As a direct result of its reckless mismanagement, Britain's biggest water supplier is being placed into special measures. The action means it will face far more intrusive oversight under which it must demonstrate that its parlous finances stack up. It is the first time that Ofwat has used such powers since its formation nearly 40 years ago.\n\nThe company cannot complain. Ofwat officials are scathing about its proposals in the face of intense pressure to clean up its act. Despite having months to put forward a credible plan that regulators could take seriously, Ofwat criticised Thames Water's \"inadequate\" business plan on Thursday morning, claiming it not only \"lacked ambition\" but was submitted \"late and incomplete\".\n\nThe watchdog also revealed that \"parts of the plan did not have the assurances of Thames' own board\", which led to it limiting the amount the company can charge customers. This prompted Ofwat director Chris Walters to remark: \"It is difficult for us to stand behind a plan that a board can't stand behind.\"\n\nCritics will say the regulator should have gone further. Indeed, reports of a planned government crackdown are proof that it could have imposed tougher conditions. Environment Secretary Steve Reed has drafted measures including banning bonuses for executives of heavily polluting water companies, imposing criminal charges on the worst lawbreakers and introducing tougher monitoring of sewage overflows.\n\nThe watchdog has instead sought to strike a sensible balance. It's a bloody nose for the more greedy suppliers, yet it acknowledges that our leaky Victorian infrastructure desperately requires investment.\n\nAt the same time, despite what the water industry's cheerleaders say, there is still room for shareholders to make a return - they just won't be as generous. The challenge for Thames will be to identify the investors willing to accept more modest profits.\n\nA bigger barrier will be a balance sheet stretched to breaking point by an \u00a318bn debt pile that is getting bigger. The company's worsening cash crunch means it is having to increasingly draw down on what's left of its borrowing facilities just to stay afloat.\n\nWithout a proper restructuring plan that includes a big debt write-off, the scramble for billions of new equity is likely to prove fruitless. If that means temporary nationalisation, so be it. The bailout of energy supplier Bulb left the taxpayer with a \u00a33bn bill and virtually the entire costs have since been recovered.\n\nThere should be no doubt about the underlying message here. An era in which financial rewards for investors and industry executives were completely disproportionate to the service provided looks to be over, and that can only be a blessing for millions of contributed to a situation in which no single river in England is considered to be in good overall health, and beauty spots including Windermere in the Lake District have been polluted.\n\nStorm 3.6 million hours in 2023.\n\nWater utilities have also been hit by multimillion-pound fines for repeated and damaging illegal pollution in the last five years, and there is concern about the levels {"uri": "8220539681", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "13:18:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T13:18:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T13:18:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/bills/article-13623421/How-water-bill-rise-help-prevent-higher-costs.html", "title": "How much YOUR water bill will rise in the next five years", "body": "Some areas will see 44% bill hikes - with only one region due to see lower prices\n\nHousehold water bills are set to rise by an average of \u00a394 over the next five years - with some unlucky regions seeing bills go up by almost \u00a3200.\n\nOne area of the country should see bills fall, although by just \u00a312.\n\nThe water bill changes are laid out in proposals by regulator Ofwat, which has analysed the spending plans of English and Welsh water companies.\n\nThese water firms gave Ofwat their five-year spending plans in October 2023.\n\nCapital punishment: Thames Water, which serves London and parts of the home counties, could be re-nationalised if it does not meet tough new plans from water regulator Ofwat\n\nMost argued that bill hikes were needed to pay for infrastructure improvements - including cutting down on the scandal of sewage being pumped into waterways and seas.\n\nNow the regulator has now set out the bill changes it thinks are reasonable, and has put one water firm, Thames Water, into special measures.\n\nOfwat will make a final decision on the exact level of bill changes in December 2024.\n\nThe highest projected bill hikes by far are for customers of Southern Water, which covers Kent, Hampshire, the Isle of Wight, East Sussex and West Sussex.\n\nThese households will see bill rises of almost half (44 per cent) if Ofwat officially signs off its proposals.\n\nHere is how the regulator wants water bills to change in your area.\n\nThe water firms with the steepest planned bill hikes Water company Average bill now Average bill by 2030Difference % change Southern Water \u00a3420\u00a3603 +\u00a3183 +44% Hafren Dyfrdwy \u00a3396 \u00a3524 +\u00a3128 +32% D\u0175r Cymru \u00a3466 \u00a3603 +\u00a3137 +29% Yorkshire Water \u00a3430 \u00a3537 +\u00a3107 +25% Thames Water \u00a3436 \u00a3535 +\u00a399 +23% Severn Trent Water \u00a3403 \u00a3496 +\u00a393 +23% United Utilities \u00a3442 \u00a3536 +\u00a394 +21% Anglian Water \u00a3491 \u00a3557 +\u00a366 +13% South West Water \u00a3497 \u00a3561 +\u00a364 +13% Northumbrian Water \u00a3415 \u00a3460 +\u00a345 +11% Wessex Water \u00a3508 \u00a3497 -\u00a312 -2% Source: Ofwat\n\nMike Keil, chief executive of the Consumer Council for Water (CCW), said: 'Millions of people will feel upset and anxious at the prospect of these water bill rises and question the fairness of them given some water companies' track record of failure and poor service.\n\n'Customers understand investment is urgently needed, but they need reassurance that every pound of their money is going to be well spent.\n\n'Trust in water companies has never been lower and that won't change until people see and experience a difference - whether that's having the confidence to swim at their favourite beach or receiving help if they are struggling to pay their bill.'\n\nRising tide: Average water bills are likely to be more than \u00a3450 per year in all regions of England and Wales by 2029, with some going over \u00a3600\n\nHow to save money on water bills\n\nConsider a water meter\n\nAround 40 per cent of households in England and Wales not do not have a water meter, and some of these would save money on water bills by getting one fitted.\n\nGetting a water meter is usually the best way of saving money on bills, for those that don't use an above-average amount of water.\n\nNot everyone will save with a meter, but water companies will usually give you two years to trial one and allow you to switch back if you are unhappy.\n\nWater firms do not have to agree to fit a water meter, for example if doing so would be costly or counterproductive. This might be the case if multiple residences share the same water pipes.\n\nMeanwhile, in some areas, having one is compulsory if the water company requests it.\n\nThe CCW has a calculator that helps you understand if a water meter could save you money.\n\nHowever, the rule of thumb is that a water bill could lower your bills if you live in a property with a high 'rateable value' (the formula used to set estimated water bills), do not use much water and/or live alone.\n\nMeter ruler: Many water bill savings are only possible if you are one of the minority of households that have a water meter fitted, which can monitor exactly how much you are using\n\nUse less water if you can\n\nIf you have a water meter fitted, using less water means paying lower bills.\n\nWater bills for homes with these meters are made up of fees for water used, as well as daily standing charges.\n\nBut using less water also means lower energy bills, as much of the water homes use is heated first.\n\nCCW figures show that if every person in a family of four reduced their daily shower time by two minutes, they could save around \u00a3280 a year in water and energy combined costs.\n\nFix leaks and upgrade thirsty appliances\n\nLikewise, fixing leaks early can save you money on water bills - again if you have a meter fitted.\n\nRead More Getting a new toilet could save you \u00a3109 a year on water bills\n\nSigns of a water leak include the obvious - drips, dampness, walls, floors and ceilings changing colour, mould and a musty smell.\n\nBut some water leaks can be harder to spot. For example, wet patches or greener spots in your garden can indicate a water leak from an underground pipe.\n\nLikewise, low boiler pressure can indicate a leak in your hot water system.\n\nUpdating some of your appliances at the end of their life can also save huge amounts on water bills.\n\nFor example, even replacing your old toilet with a dual flush model could save more than \u00a3100 a year, according to B&Q owner Kingfisher.\n\nThis is because toilets are responsible for 22 per cent of all the water used in a home, and a dual flush loo lets users regulate how much is used in every flush.\n\nCheck if you are eligible for a social tariff\n\nEvery water company in England and Wales has its own social tariff scheme designed to help customers on a low income.\n\nBut who is eligible and the level of support offered varies hugely from company to company. In some instances, bills can be reduced by as much as 90 per cent.\n\nCCW has a list of social tariffs and criteria on its website.\n\nFor example, Thames Water's social tariff is called Water Help.\n\nIt cuts water bills by 50 per cent for homes where this costs more than 5 per cent of their net income.\n\nAlmost two million homes - or 15 per cent - are eligible for water social tariffs but not signed up to one, according to the CCW.\n\nFive water companies use their own profits to help offer cheaper tariffs.\n\nThese are Welsh Water, Severn Trent, Yorkshire Water, SES Water and United Utilities.\n\nConsider the WaterSure scheme\n\nWaterSure is a Government programme run by water firms to discount bills for qualifying households in England and Wales.\n\nTo qualify, a household must be on certain benefits, such as Universal Credit, Pension Credit, Housing Benefit or income-related Employment and Support Allowance.\n\nMost of the benefits on the list are for those on low incomes.\n\nA household signing up to WaterSure will also need large amounts of water, either for medical reasons or because it has a lot of young children.\n\nThey must also either have a water meter fitted, or be on a waiting list for one.\n\nWaterSure provides discounts to both the water and sewerage parts of a water bill.\n\nTo apply, you will need to fill in a form from your water company, and will likely need to prove you are on benefits and have a qualifying medical condition.\n\nConsider water-saving gadgets\n\nMany devices that help save water and money are handed out for free by water firms, though this does depend on where you live.\n\nThese widgets include water-saving shower heads, water butts and so on.\n\nTo find out what you can get, put your postcode into the Save Water Save Money website.\n\nSAVE MONEY, MAKE MONEYInvesting boostInvesting boost5.09% on cash for Isa investorsLearn MoreLearn MoreCash Isa at 5.17%Cash Isa at 5.17%Includes 0.88% bonus for one yearLearn MoreLearn MoreFree share offerFree share offerNo account fee and free share dealingLearn MoreLearn More5.78% savings5.78% savings365 day notice accountLearn MoreLearn MoreFibre broadbandFibre broadband\u00a350 BT reward card -
