{"uri": "8220455633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "12:27:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T12:27:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T12:26:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.wired-gov.net/wg/news.nsf/articles/Ofwat%2Bsets%2Bout%2Brecord%2B88%2Bbillion%2Bupgrade%2Bto%2Bdeliver%2Bcleaner%2Brivers%2Band%2Bseas%2Band%2Bbetter%2Bservices%2Bfor%2Bcustomers%2B11072024132000?open", "title": "Ofwat sets out record \u00a388 billion upgrade to deliver cleaner rivers and seas, and better services for customers | Ofwat", "body": "Ofwat has today proposed allowing a spending package of \u00a388bn by water companies\n\n\u00a335bn of the expenditure reflects the investment needed to reduce pollution, improve customer service, river and bathing water quality, and deliver greater resilience to the impact of climate change. This is more than a trebling of the level of investment in the 2020 to 2025 period.\n\nThe total expenditure proposed is \u00a316bn lower than in companies' business plans. This reflects Ofwat's analysis of those plans, removing or reducing costs where expenditure is insufficiently justified, inefficient or for activity for which companies have already been funded; customers will not pay twice.\n\nThe average bill increase for water and wastewater companies will be \u00a319 a year over five years (\u00a394 in total), excluding inflation. Companies' business plans proposed increases averaging \u00a3144 over five years. Ofwat's interventions have reduced the level of bill increases proposed by companies. For example, Thames Water's proposed increase of \u00a3191 by 2030 has been reduced to \u00a399; Severn Trent's proposed increase of \u00a3144 has been reduced to \u00a393.\n\nCompanies have been required to prepare for the future by setting their plans in the context of a 25-year delivery strategy. These proposals include the work of the regulators' joint team RAPID, which is helping to accelerate the delivery of \u00a317bn of new water assets including 6 reservoirs, some of which are part of the wider programme of major projects; in total 9 new reservoirs are proposed.\n\nThe overall investment programme will deliver improvements in the environment, strengthen the resilience of water supplies and improve day-to-day customer service.\n\nThe cost of this investment will initially be funded by shareholders or through borrowing, with these costs then recovered through customers' bills in this 5-year period and beyond. Ofwat has proposed a rate of return of 3.72%. This is above the level set for 2020 to 2025, reflecting increases in the cost of finance and the need to ensure the sector can raise the finance necessary to fund such a significant programme of investment.\n\nDavid Black, Chief Executive, Ofwat said:\n\n\"Customers want to see radical change in the way water companies care for the environment.\n\n\"Our draft decisions on company plans approve a tripling of investment to make sustained improvement to customer service and the environment at a fair price for customers.\n\n\"These proposals aim to deliver a 44% reduction in spills from storm overflows compared to levels in 2021. We expect all companies to embrace innovation and go further and faster to reduce spills wherever possible.\n\n\"Today's announcement also increases the resilience of our water supplies to the impact of climate change and will reduce how much water is taken from rivers by enabling a range of long-term water supply projects, which includes plans for 9 reservoirs.\n\n\"Let me be very clear to water companies. We will be closely scrutinising the delivery of their plans and will hold them to account to deliver real improvements to the environment and for customers and on their investment programmes.\"\n\nEvery five years Ofwat is required to set the price, investment and service package for water companies in England and Wales. Today's proposals are part of the 2024 Price Review (PR24) and cover the period from 1 April 2025 to 31 March 2030.\n\nInvestment\n\nAs with previous price reviews the level of the investment programme is principally driven by environmental requirements, set out through the statutory planning processes led by the Environment Agency, Natural Resources Wales, and the UK and Welsh Governments.\n\nThis has led to companies' proposed total expenditure increasing by \u00a329bn - this is split between a \u00a35bn increase in the core costs for running their business and a \u00a324bn increase in expenditure to meet requirements set by Governments and for other environmental improvements.\n\nPart of Ofwat's role as the economic regulator is to scrutinise companies' cost proposals, to ensure they deliver efficiently; this has led to a \u00a316bn reduction. The reductions have applied to proposals where additional expenditure allowances have not been justified, including where customers are being asked to pay twice, or where proposed costs do not reflect efficient delivery. Where companies can provide additional evidence to justify their proposals it will be considered by Ofwat ahead of final decisions.\n\nThe increase in the scale of investment will challenge companies' capacity to deliver. It is encouraging that over the past 18 months many companies have strengthened their relationships with key suppliers to enable the step-up in activity that will be needed. Ofwat is putting in place additional processes for Thames Water and Southern Water which face some of the greatest delivery challenges; approval for parts of their funding will be phased over time, linking it to progress on delivering their investment plans.\n\nOfwat has established new approaches for large schemes to ensure that investments of over \u00a3100m are delivered as efficiently as possible, improving value for customers and outcomes for the environment. 21 large schemes in today's proposals will be delivered by these new approaches, enabling capital and operational cost savings as well as a reduction in financing costs, while maintaining quality.\n\nIn addition to these large schemes Ofwat has a programme of 18 major projects ranging from reservoirs to water transfers and treatment works. These projects will attract around \u00a326 billion pounds of new investment to the sector over the next 5 - 15 years through innovative competitive delivery models. Third parties will compete to design, build and in some cases operate and maintain this essential infrastructure, driving best value for money for customers. To qualify for these models major projects are over \u00a3200 million and distinct from the rest of the company networks.\n\nThis builds on the experience from the \u00a34.5bn Thames Tideway super sewer, which is currently being commissioned. This is showing how the use of competitive models for delivery and innovation in finance arrangements helps deliver better outcomes for customers and the environment.\n\nThe increased allowance for companies' base expenditure reflects measures including: increased expenditure in maintaining long term asset health by increasing the rate of mains replacement; accommodating population growth including by increasing capacity at sewage treatment works; and the effect of higher energy costs.\n\nBills\n\nThe increase in investment will lead to an increase in customer bills. Ofwat is committed to fair bills for current and future customers:\n\nThe average bill increase for water and wastewater companies for the five years from 1 April 2025 is \u00a394 (21%), around \u00a319 per year.\n\nOfwat welcomes commitments from a number of companies to increase substantially the level of support given to customers who need a helping hand. Overall, nearly \u00a3500 million is going to be made available for the five-year period.\n\nA breakdown of bill changes by company is provided at the end of this statement.\n\nDelivering improved performance\n\nPR24 also sets performance targets which companies are expected to achieve, with rewards or penalties for outperformance or underperformance. There are 8 new environmental targets including:\n\nA fair return for investors\n\nInvestment in the water sector is financed up front by investors and repaid by customers over time. Companies will therefore need to access additional debt and equity to support the investment programme. Since 2021 over \u00a34.6bn of equity has been raised by the sector; business plans identified a further new equity funding requirement of \u00a37bn by 2030. Some water companies will need to take further steps to strengthen their financial resilience and Ofwat has required further assurance about their financial resilience in 2025-30 and beyond\n\nOfwat has set the allowed rate of return for companies at 3.72%, reflecting a cost of equity of 4.8% and debt at 2.84% and underpinned by a gearing ratio of 55%. At these levels, and taking account of the overall balance of risk and return in these proposals, Ofwat is satisfied that an efficient company can finance its functions.\n\nThames Water\n\nOfwat has allowed Thames Water \u00a316.9bn to invest on improving services for customers and the environment. Around 20% of the \u00a316.9bn funding (worth more than \u00a33bn) is conditional on the company demonstrating it is ready and able to effectively deploy investment or that the investment will be effectively and efficiently targeted. This is in addition to the price review process that will see customers' money clawed back if investment is not delivered.\n\nGiven concerns about the performance of the company, Ofwat is imposing a Turnaround Oversight Regime on the company. This will include:\n\nIn addition, we are considering appointing an Independent Monitor to monitor and report on the company's progress, including against its transformation plan. The Independent Monitor would report back to us and be entitled to full access to company information.\n\nNext steps\n\nToday's announcement sets out Ofwat's draft decisions based on its review of company business plans.\n\nThese draft decisions are open for consultation and responses are welcome from customers, stakeholders and water companies. The deadline for consultation responses is 12 noon on 28 August 2024.\n\nOfwat expects to publish its final decisions on 19 December 2024. If companies do not agree with the final decisions, they have two months from the date of publication to ask for an appeal to the Competition and Markets Authority.\n\nA consultation has also been published today on a proposed modification to companies' licences. This would allow Ofwat to if necessary due to unforeseen circumstances.\n\nNotes\n\nAll figures before inflation. be realistic about the levels of investment needed\", and urged the regulator to let them get on with an unprecedented overhaul of the country's water infrastructure, campaigners had a very different take.\n\nSewage spills from water infrastructure have contributed to a situation in which no single river in England is considered to be in good overall health, and beauty spots including Windermere in the Lake District have been polluted.\n\nStorm overflows - which release untreated wastewater into rivers and seas when there is heavy rain to prevent sewers becoming overwhelmed - dumped sewage into the environment 464,056 times and for more than 3.6 million hours in 2023.\n\nWater utilities have also been hit by multimillion-pound fines for repeated and damaging illegal pollution in the last five years, and there is concern about the levels of leaks from water infrastructure - especially in times of drought when hosepipe bans are imposed.\n\nAnd worse is to come as climate change and worsening weather extremes, from downpours to drought, pile more pressure on supplies.\n\nThe General Election campaign made clear that the public is fed up with those in power turning a blind eye to \"insulting price hikes\" by water companies must be blocked.\n\n\"It is a national scandal that these disgraced firms are demanding more money from families and pensioners in a cost-of-living crisis, of consumer bill prices and investment spending, Ofwat has allowed UK water companies to increase bills by only 21% by 2030.\n\nWhile this is positive news for consumers, it significantly falls short Ofwat has \"got this wrong.\"\n\n\"This is an unrealistic and unfair decision from Ofwat, and our economy and environment will pay the price,\" he added.\n\nAnother spokesperson for Water UK described it as \"the biggest ever cut in investment,\" contrasting sharply with Ofwat boss David Black's assertion that the plans represent the \"biggest ever\" investment in the water sector.\n\n11.41am: than expected, while construction output also surprised to the upside.\n\nThe pound rallied in response, as the markets began to wonder if the Bank of England intends to delay anticipated interest rate cuts.\n\n\"After all, cutting rates is something a central bank does to stimulate a lackluster economy, not grease the wheels for one already moving ahead,\" stated Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell.\n\nMould added: \"That said, momentum could easily lose pace, particularly if the jobs market weakens and sticky inflation causes consumers to stay cautious on spending.\"\n\nIG businesses.\n\nBut Tom Lee, head of trading proposition at Hargreaves Lansdown, warned that certain measures being implemented by the FCA could harm shareholders.\n\nWhile \"a successful listings regime which supports our home market is essential,\" Lee said that \"making the UK an attractive place to list has to be balanced with rights for shareholders and ensuring that the quality of the market is not diluted.\"\n\nUnder the new listing rules coming into effect at the end of the month, listed companies will not require shareholder approval on significant or related-party transactions. They will also have more flexibility around enhanced voting rights.\n\n\"We have been concerned that the plan to remove shareholder votes on significant and related-party transactions would dilute investors' rights,\" said Lee. \"We will watch closely as these new rules embed.\"\n\nOn the bright side, Lee noted that retail access to primary and secondary listings will be enhanced under the new rules.\n\n\"The demand from retail investors to buy into the equities market is there, and regulatory change should support this demand.\n\n\"Boosting retail investment on the stock exchange will have wider market benefits, providing depth and liquidity, as well as boosting interest in investment with the wider public, unlocking further capital for UK-listed companies.\"\n\n10.01am: FCA overhauls UK listing standards\n\nThe Financial Conduct Authority has unveiled the biggest overhaul of UK listing requirements in decades, aimed at rejuvenating London's flailing capital markets.\n\nThe primary goal of the overhaul is to make it easier and more attractive for companies to list their shares in the UK, with the biggest change being the scrapping of Britain's two-tier listing structure.\n\nHistorically, Listings have been divided into primary and secondary segments, with the latter having stricter reporting standards.\n\nA single category called 'commercial companies' will replace this structure when the rules into into effect at the end of this month.\n\nKey changes include removing the need for shareholder votes on significant or related party transactions and The situation has become so bad that Thames warned there was a \"material uncertainty\" over whether it can continue beyond the next 12 months.\n\nMr Weston, 60, is now racing to stitch up a funding deal with major infrastructure and pension investors that would inject fresh capital into the group and stave off a Labour nationalisation. Documents published on Tuesday revealed that he needs to find \u00a33.25bn from investors and strike a deal with bondholders, while also keeping regulators happy.\n\nThames has been struggling for several months owing to its complex financial structure.\n\nAfter its tortured ownership under Macquarie, which took out billions in dividends, the group has been left with \u00a315.3bn worth of debt and a creaking 19th century infrastructure dating back to when it was built by engineer Joseph Bazalgette.\n\nFor the new Labour government, the crisis at Thames poses the first real test of its mettle amid questions over whether a failure by Mr Weston to strike his deal could trigger nationalisation. Will Mr Weston succeed and live up to his battlefield status, or will Sir Keir Starmer be forced to step in and revive memories of Labour's prior nationalisations?\n\nThe Government has so far indicated it has no desire to bring Thames back under state control, but if Mr Weston fails the taxpayer could become the investor of last resort.\n\nThe new Business Secretary, Jonathan Reynolds, said there is no desire to re-nationalise Thames while Chancellor Rachel Reeves has also said a move \"doesn't stack up\" against the party's fiscal rules.\n\nYet if Mr Weston fails to get a deal done in time, Ministers could be forced to act\n\nAgainst this backdrop, Labour has already hinted it wants to take a more interventionist role with water companies. Its manifesto pledged to put \"failing\" water companies into \"special measures\".\n\nThe Government has so far failed to spell out what this means, and Mr Weston himself admitted he was confused about the concept.\n\n\"I don't yet fully understand what the special measures referred to in the Labour manifesto are,\" he admitted on Tuesday.\n\nAmid rising anger over pollution and sewage in water supplies, there are growing calls from backbench MPs to nationalise water groups.\n\nLeft-wing Labour MPs such as Kate Osamor have previously called for Thames Water to be brought back into public ownership, while Clive Lewis has also indicated support for ditching a capitalist model for water companies.\n\nRuth Cadbury, a more centrist Labour MP, whose constituency covers the River Thames, backed the Government to introduce special measures for failing water companies after Thames's update today.\n\n\"I know the Government is not saying nationalisation, but what's more important is ensuring that in the years to come we have clean water to drink and they process sewage without polluting our rivers and beaches.\n\n\"My understanding is that special measures do not mean nationalisation. Nationalisation is very structural and what my constituents want is outcomes - and the structure of how this happens isn't necessarily the answer.\n\n\"Our front bench is not ruling it in, nor are was a \"possibility\" there was \"a lot more water to go under the bridge\".\n\n\"It is extremely early days,\" he said. \"We have been in contact with the Government, as you would imagine, as part of the normal course of process and I have every confidence that we will have discussions, as appropriate, with them in the near future.\"\n\nFor the former British Gas executive, who is widely considered to have brought a fresh reality to proceedings and displays a calmness under pressure that reflects his military background, his most pressing task now is to find new investors to take the strain.\n\nThames's nine current shareholders, which includes the Canadian pension fund giant Omers and UK groups like Hermes and USS, have failed to commit to any fresh funding owing to uncertainty over Thames' future.\n\nEarlier this year they pulled the plug on an emergency \u00a3500m equity injection after Thames was deemed \"uninvestable\" in its current state.\n\nWorking with his advisers, Mr Weston is now planning to launch a charm offensive in the autumn to lure new investors to stump up \u00a33.25bn.\n\nHe suggested there was \"interest in the market\" to buy shares in the company and that \"informal discussions\" had already taken place.\n\n\"We are wholly focused on bringing new equity into Thames Water. We will go to the market and we will look at a broad church of investors\" he said.\n\n\"Some of those investors may or may not be some of our existing shareholders, that isn't a matter entirely for them.\"\n\nOne glimmer of hope for Thames is the booming interest in infrastructure investments from major North American investors. The likes of BlackRock, Brookfield and KKR have all sung the praises of infrastructure in recent months due to its stable returns.\n\nYet to lure investors in, investors need to be able to make a healthy profit and that hinges on the role of Britain's water regulator Ofwat.\n\nThe regulator, led by chief executive David Black, will deliver a key verdict on July 11 by ruling on whether five-year business plans put forward by Britain's 20 water companies can proceed. Thames wants to hike customer bills by 56pc to an average of \u00a3608 per year by 2030.\n\nIt says the ratepayer hike is required for a \u00a320bn investment plan and to make the company attractive to investors.\n\nIf Ofwat agrees, the fresh funding package could unlock a new wave of investors into the group and stave off insolvency. Fail, and Thames could struggle to attract the cash needed to survive.\n\nThe problem poses serious questions for the new Labour government who are keen to both protect ratepayers from bill rises amid the cost of living crisis and maintain its pro-business stance.\n\nLuke Hickmore, a leading bondholder in Thames Water, said Thames' latest warning over whether it can continue was \"a shot across the bows of Ofwat\".\n\n\"It just continues to amp the pressure on them,\" he said.\n\n\"Saying these are things that need to be covered to avoid going into special administration, which would be very bad for the sector, this is part of that whole cat and mouse game between the regulator and Thames.\n\n\"I do think this is quite a careful game for Ofwat to play because you don't want to spook investors.\"\n\nIt is understood that Labour was in contact with Thames bondholders before the election, with creditors lobbying against any plans to force losses on lenders.\n\nMr Weston suggested Ofwat could push through a bill hike for Thames while also cracking down on other water companies. He pointed to the unique challenges of supplying water to London, a city with nine million people.\n\n\"Operating in London, one of the most congested cities in the world with an infrastructure that's 150 years old and that needs replacing, is a very different prospect to operating elsewhere in the country,\" he said.\n\nMr Weston, who previously led energy provider Aggreko, said getting shareholders to inject equity was better than forcing taxpayers to shoulder the burden.\n\n\"I don't think it's in the interest of anyone that we go into special administration that is not good for our stakeholders. "body": "UK's biggest water company has just \u00a31.8bn in cash - and may be forced to seek a bailout\n\nAs a former Royal Artillery army officer, Thames Water chief executive Chris Weston is used to handling high explosives.\n\nNow the former military man is having to draw on his battlefield experience to defuse a ticking time bomb at Thames Water, which threatens to detonate under the new Labour government.\n\nThe utility giant, Britain's largest water company with 16 million customers, has warned investors that it could run out of cash next year if a new consortium of shareholders is not found to solve its funding crisis.\n\nThe group has just \u00a31.8bn of cash left to tide it over until next May and \u00a315bn of debts, leaving it dangling on a cliff edge of uncertainty which could prompt it to seek a government bailout.\n\nThe situation has become so bad that Thames warned there was a \"material uncertainty\" over whether it can continue beyond the next 12 months.\n\nMr Weston, 60, is now racing against the clock to stitch up a funding deal with major infrastructure and pension investors to inject fresh capital into the group and stave off a Labour nationalisation.\n\nDocuments published on Tuesday revealed that he needs to find \u00a33.25bn from investors and strike a deal with bondholders, while also keeping regulators happy.\n\nThames has been struggling for several months owing to its complex financial structure.\n\nAfter its tortured ownership under Macquarie, which took out billions in dividends, the group has been left with \u00a315.3bn worth of debt and a creaking 19th century infrastructure dating back to when it was built by engineer Joseph Bazalgette.\n\nFor the new Labour government, the crisis at Thames poses the first real test of its mettle amid questions over whether a failure by Mr Weston to strike his deal could trigger nationalisation.\n\nWill Mr Weston succeed and live up to his battlefield status, or will Sir Keir Starmer be forced to step in and revive memories of Labour's prior nationalisations?\n\nThe Government has so far indicated it has no desire to bring Thames back under state control but if Mr Weston fails, the taxpayer could become the investor of last resort.\n\nThe new Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds said there is no desire to re-nationalise Thames while Chancellor Rachel Reeves has also said a move \"doesn't stack up\" against the party's fiscal rules.\n\nYet if Mr Weston fails to get a deal done in time, Ministers could be forced to act\n\nAgainst this backdrop, Labour has already hinted it wants to take a more interventionist role with water companies.\n\nIts manifesto pledged to put \"failing\" water companies into \"special measures\".\n\nThe Government has so far failed to spell out what this means, and Mr Weston himself admitted he was confused about the concept.\n\n\"I don't yet fully understand what the special measures referred to in the Labour manifesto are,\" he admitted on Tuesday.\n\nYet amid rising anger over pollution and sewage in water supplies, there are growing calls to nationalise water groups from backbench MPs.\n\nLeft-wing Labour MPs such as Kate Osamor have previously called for Thames Water to be brought back into public ownership, while Clive Lewis has also indicated support for ditching a capitalist model for water companies.\n\nRuth Cadbury, a more centrist Labour MP, whose constituency covers the River Thames, backed the Government to introduce special measures for failing water companies after Thames' fresh update today.\n\n\"I know the Government is not saying nationalisation but what's more important is ensuring that in the years to come we have clean water to drink and they process sewage without polluting our rivers and beaches.\n\n\"My understanding is that special measures do not mean nationalisation. Nationalisation is very structural and what my constituents want is outcomes and the structure of how this happens isn't necessarily the answer.\n\n\"Our front bench is not ruling it in, nor are they ruling it out.\"\n\nIndustry figures are increasingly fearful that if Thames goes into special administration, the Government could seek to nationalise the whole water sector.\n\nThe Earl of Devon, a crossbench peer, recently highlighted the wider industry issue, pointing out that growing regulatory burdens on water companies such as the Environment Act was making it \"unprofitable\" to invest in the water industry and that nationalisation was \"at some point inevitable\".\n\nMr Weston would not be drawn on his detailed discussions with the Government but said that although a bailout was a \"possibility\" there was \"a lot more water to go under the bridge\".\n\n\"It is extremely early days,\" he said. \"We have been in contact with the Government, as you would imagine, as part of the normal course of process and I have every confidence that we will have discussions as appropriate with them in the near future.\"\n\nFor the former British Gas executive, who is widely considered to have brought a fresh reality to proceedings and displays a calm under pressure which reflects his military background, his most pressing task now is to find new investors to take the strain.\n\nThames' nine current shareholders, which includes the Canadian pension fund giant Omers and UK groups like Hermes and USS, have failed to commit to any fresh funding owing to uncertainty over Thames' future.\n\nEarlier this year they pulled the plug on an emergency \u00a3500m equity injection after Thames was deemed \"uninvestable\" in its current state.\n\nWorking with his advisers, Mr Weston is now planning to launch a charm offensive in the autumn to lure new investors to stump up \u00a33.25bn.\n\nHe suggested there was \"interest in the market\" to buy shares in the company and that \"informal discussions\" had already taken place.\n\n\"We are wholly focused on bringing new equity into Thames Water. We will go to the market and we will look at a broad church of investors\" he said.\n\n\"Some of those investors may or may not be some of our existing shareholders, that isn't a matter entirely for them.\"\n\nOne glimmer of hope for Thames is the booming interest in infrastructure investments from major North American investors. The likes of BlackRock, Brookfield and KKR have all sung the praises of infrastructure in recent months due to its stable returns.\n\nYet to lure investors in, investors need to be able to make a healthy profit and that hinges on the role of Britain's water regulator Ofwat.\n\nThe regulator, led by chief executive David Black, will deliver a key verdict on July 11 by ruling on whether five-year business plans put forward by Britain's 20 water companies can proceed.\n\nThames wants to hike customer bills by 56pc to an average of \u00a3608 per year by 2030.\n\nIt says the ratepayer hike is required for a \u00a320bn investment plan and to make the company attractive to investors.\n\nIf Ofwat agrees, the fresh funding package could unlock a new wave of investors into the group and stave off insolvency. Fail, and Thames could struggle to attract the cash needed to survive.\n\nThe problem poses serious questions for the new Labour government who are keen to both protect ratepayers from bill hikes amid the cost of living crisis and maintain its pro-business stance.\n\nLuke Hickmore, a leading bondholder in Thames Water, said Thames' latest warning over whether it can continue was \"a shot across the bows of Ofwat\".\n\n\"It just continues to amp the pressure on them,\" he said.\n\n\"Saying these are things that need to be covered to avoid going into special administration, which would be very bad for the sector, this is part of that whole cat and mouse game between the regulator and Thames.\n\n\"I do think this is quite a careful game for Ofwat to play because you don't want to spook investors.\"\n\nIt is understood that Labour was in contact with Thames bondholders before the election, with creditors lobbying against any plans to force losses on lenders.\n\nMr Weston suggested Ofwat could push through a bill hike for Thames while also cracking down on other water companies. He pointed to the unique challenges of supplying water to London, a city with nine million people.\n\n\"Operating in London, one of the most congested cities in the world with an infrastructure that's 150 years old and that needs replacing, is a very different prospect to operating elsewhere in the country,\" he said.\n\nMr Weston, who previously led energy provider Aggreko, said getting shareholders to inject equity was better than forcing taxpayers to shoulder the burden.\n\n\"I don't think it's in the interest of anyone that we go into special administration that is not good for our stakeholders. It will probably go to the taxpayer so it is not a solution.\n\n\"Special administration is absolutely not inevitable. There is an alternative,\" he said.\n\nTime is not on his or the Government's side, however.", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, "authors": [], For years, Ofwat sat back and did little as the sector accumulated gargantuan debts, with the effect of turbo-boosting returns to absentee shareholders, neglecting desperately needed investment and service in the process - and polluting our waterways with abandon to boot.\n\nWith Thames Water now on the brink of collapse and public anger mounting at the situation, Ofwat appears to have woken up to the national scandal taking place before its eyes by rejecting water companies' demands for steep bill increases in an interim verdict on suppliers' five-year business plans.\n\nThat is to be applauded. If Ofwat were to emerge from these negotiations with any credibility it had to get tough, particularly given the eye-watering increases some suppliers have asked for.\n\nSouthern Water - one of the more financially stretched companies - topped the league of shame with a proposed rise of more than 90pc once inflation is taken into account between 2025 and 2030. That's equivalent to bill increases of nearly \u00a3306. Industry pariah Thames wants to ramp up bills by 56pc to nearly \u00a3627 per year.\n\nThursday's ruling will come as a severe shock to some, then, after the watchdog ruled that bills will rise by \u00a319 a year or 21pc on average by the end of the decade - a third less than the combined increases that the 16 companies had submitted.\n\nPredictably, it didn't take long for the howls of protest from suppliers to be heard. Industry lobbyist Water UK warned that Ofwat had swung too far the other way and risks killing off investment by watering down returns too heavily. Bemoaning \"the biggest ever cut in investment\", lobbyist Water UK claimed: \"If it doesn't put this right, Ofwat will be repeating the mistakes of the past.\"\n\nNonsense. It's the sort of tin-eared response that merely underlines the extent to which the industry still doesn't get it, despite the uproar at its woeful track record and the dramatic consequence of years of debt-fuelled ownership.\n\nThis is a wake-up call. Suppliers are finally paying the price for their incompetence and greed. Investors have had more than a decade of being allowed to financially engineer these businesses during which the media, campaigners, and politicians warned that the consequences would be extremely bad - but they didn't listen.\n\nIt couldn't go on forever. A system that privatises the profits during the go-go years cannot socialise the losses when the music stops. What shareholders are effectively asking the rest of us to accept is for them to have unlimited upside and for all the risk to sit with bill-payers so that they can walk away when it all goes wrong and the public is left to pick up the pieces. If Ofwat hadn't got tough then there was a real risk of it creating moral hazard.\n\nIn making an example of Thames, the chances of that happening are further reduced. As a direct result of its reckless mismanagement, Britain's biggest water supplier is being placed into special measures. The action means it will face far more intrusive oversight under which it must demonstrate that its parlous finances stack up. It is the first time that Ofwat has used such powers since its formation nearly 40 years ago.\n\nCritics will say Ofwat should have gone further. Indeed, reports of a planned government crackdown are proof that it could have imposed tougher conditions. Environment Secretary Steve Reed has drafted measures including banning bonuses for executives of heavily polluting water companies, imposing criminal charges on the worst lawbreakers and introducing tougher monitoring of sewage overflows.\n\nThe watchdog has instead sought to strike a sensible balance. It's a bloody nose for the more greedy suppliers, yet it acknowledges that our leaky Victorian infrastructure desperately requires investment at the same time as allowing for shareholders to still make a decent return, whatever its proponents may say.\n\nBut there should be no doubt about the underlying message here. An era in which financial rewards for investors and industry executives were completely disproportionate to the service provided looks to be over, and that can only be a blessing for millions of "FTSE 100 Live: UK economy pulls forward, water bill debate erupts, pound rallies", "body": "FTSE 100 up 11 points to 8,205 Thames Water bills to rise UK economy grows more than expected 12.53pm: Water bill price hikes a 'bitter pill' says Labour\n\nLabour chancellor Rachel Reeves has called the planned 21% increase in water bills by 2030 a \"bitter pill\" for Brits to swallow.\n\nUnder draft proposals released today by regulator Ofwat, water firms will be allowed to hike bills by an average of \u00a319 per year, or \u00a394 over five years to 2030.\n\n\"It's clearly a bitter pill for people who are seeing today's announcements about higher water bills,\" said Reeves.\n\n\"This reflects 14 years of failure from the Conservatives to drive investment to reduce pollution, and to ensure that families are not struggling the way that they have been with the cost-of-living crisis.\"\n\nWhile it comes at a time of public outrage over escalating sewage spills and water contamination incidents, the price hikes fall significantly short of what the water companies wanted.\n\nThames Water, for instance, will only be allowed to raise water prices by \u00a399 over the next five years, barely half of the \u00a3191 it was seeking.\n\nIn a sign that this compromise will satisfy no one, campaigners and the Liberal Democrats have robustly rubbished the price hikes as unfair, disgraceful and insulting.\n\nIndustry group Water UK was equally outraged for the opposite reason, calling the decision to not meet water companies' demands \"an unrealistic and unfair decision from Ofwat, and our economy and environment will pay the price\".\n\n12.25pm: Ofwat in water firm face-off\n\nWater regulator Ofwat is preparing for a confrontation with Britain's water executives over the austere draft determination proposals released today.\n\nIn its five-year review of consumer bill prices and investment spending, Ofwat has allowed UK water companies to increase bills by only 21% by 2030.\n\nWhile this is positive news for consumers, it significantly falls short of the water firms' expectations, raising concerns about a potential shortfall in essential infrastructure investment.\n\nDavid Henderson, chief executive of industry group Water UK, told the BBC that Ofwat has \"got this wrong.\"\n\n\"This is an unrealistic and unfair decision from Ofwat, and our economy and environment will pay the price,\" he added.\n\nAnother spokesperson for Water UK described it as \"the biggest ever cut in investment,\" contrasting sharply with Ofwat boss David Black's assertion that the plans represent the \"biggest ever\" investment in the water sector.\n\n11.41am: Pound at four-month high\n\nA spate of bullish economic figures has pushed the pound to a four-month high.\n\nGross domestic product figures show that Labour has inherited an economy growing faster than expected, while construction output also surprised to the upside.\n\nThe pound rallied in response, as the markets began to wonder if the Bank of England intends to delay anticipated interest rate cuts.\n\n\"After all, cutting rates is something a central bank does to stimulate a lackluster economy, not grease the wheels for one already moving ahead,\" stated Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell.\n\nMould added: \"That said, momentum could easily lose pace, particularly if the jobs market weakens and sticky inflation causes consumers to stay cautious on spending.\"\n\nIG data shows that rate cut expectations have been trimmed slightly, although a 25-basis-point move lower is still widely favoured in September.\n\n10.53am: Hargreaves warns of diluted investor rights under new listing regime\n\nThe Financial Conduct Authority today announced an overhaul of the UK listing regime, aimed at making London's struggling capital markets a more attractive place for global businesses.\n\nBut Tom Lee, head of trading proposition at Hargreaves Lansdown, warned that certain measures being implemented by the FCA could harm shareholders.\n\nWhile \"a successful listings regime which supports our home market is essential,\" Lee said that \"making the UK an attractive place to list has to be balanced with rights for shareholders and ensuring that the quality of the market is not diluted.\"\n\nUnder the new listing rules coming into effect at the end of the month, listed companies will not require shareholder approval on significant or related-party transactions. They will also have more flexibility around enhanced voting rights.\n\n\"We have been concerned that the plan to remove shareholder votes on significant and related-party transactions would dilute investors' rights,\" said Lee. \"We will watch closely as these new rules embed.\"\n\nOn the bright side, Lee noted that retail access to primary and secondary listings will be enhanced under the new rules.\n\n\"The demand from retail investors to buy into the equities market is there, and regulatory change should support this demand.\n\n\"Boosting retail investment on the stock exchange will have wider market benefits, providing depth and liquidity, as well as boosting interest in investment with the wider public, unlocking further capital for UK-listed companies.\"\n\n10.01am: FCA overhauls UK listing standards\n\nThe Financial Conduct Authority has unveiled the biggest overhaul of UK listing requirements in decades, aimed at rejuvenating London's flailing capital markets.\n\nThe primary goal of the overhaul is to make it easier and more attractive for companies to list their shares in the UK, with the biggest change being the scrapping of Britain's two-tier listing structure.\n\nHistorically, Listings have been divided into primary and secondary segments, with the latter having stricter reporting standards.\n\nA single category called 'commercial companies' will replace this structure when the rules into into effect at the end of this month.\n\nKey changes include removing the need for shareholder votes on significant or related party transactions and allowing flexibility around enhanced voting rights.\n\nA more detailed breakdown of the changes is available here.\n\n9.30am: Water companies buoy market after Ofwat review\n\nMore on the water sector where share price reactions suggest a bullet had been dodged especially by SouthWest Water owner Pennon.\n\nIts share price is up by a thumping 6.3% to 658p.with Severn Trent up 2.7% at 2,687p, and United Utilities 2.3% higher at 1,090p\n\nIndeed, Severn Trent and United Utilities are Footsie's biggest gainers after Ofwat's latest decision on price rises between 2025 and 2030.\n\nMidlands-focused Severn Tent had asked for a \u00a3144 rise over the five years, but got \u00a393 (23%). United Utilities gets a \u00a394 rise (21%) while Pennon's South West Water arm gets a \u00a364 (13%) rise. All exclude inflation.\n\nOfwat said in total, an average bill will rise by \u00a319 a year and pay for \u00a388 billion of spending by the sector of which \u00a335 billion will be directed towards fewer sewage spills and better water quality, including \u00a310 billion for storm overflows.\n\nFootsie up 18 at 8,211.\n\n8.55am: The morning so far\n\nThe FTSE 100 shifted to and fro when trading commenced this Thursday, but it ultimately looks to be heading in the right direction.\n\nAs of 8.55am, the blue-chip index was trading 15 points higher at 8,208, supported by a raft of bullish economic announcements.\n\nGDP figures show that the economy grew by 1.4% year on year in May, outstripping the expected growth rate of 1.2% and doubling April's 0.7% gain.\n\nMonth on month, gross domestic product grew by 0.4%, an upside surprise following a zero-growth period in April, though the data still shows \"significant room for improvement under the incoming Labour government\", according to Rob Morgan, chief investment analyst at Charles Stanley (LSE:CAY).\n\nConstruction output, meanwhile, advanced by 0.8% year-on-year in May, marking a strong rebound from a 2.1% drop in the prior month and exceeding market expectations of a 1.9% decline.\n\nWater firms Severn Trent PLC (LSE:SVT) and United Utilities Group PLC (LSE:UU.) were the two biggest FTSE 100 risers of the morning.\n\nThis follows regulator Ofwat's latest draft determination, which sets the pricing and investment agenda for British water firms.\n\nOn average, water bills are set to rise 21% by 2030, Ofwat declared.\n\nThough this is less than what the water firms wanted, Severn Trent is higher following a decent first-quarter financial update.\n\nElsewhere in company news, Dr Martens has published a bare trading update prior to its AGM meeting this morning.\n\nThe classic British footwear company said that \"trading since the start of this financial year has been in line with expectations and our guidance for (financial 2025) remains unchanged\".\n\n8.43am: Construction output grows\n\nConstruction output in the UK advanced by 0.8% year-on-year in May 2024, according to the Office for National Statistics.\n\nThis marks a significant rebound from a 2.1% drop in the prior month and exceeded market expectations of a 1.9% decline.\n\nIt was the first expansion in construction output since January.\n\nThe increase was driven by a 7.7% rise in repair and maintenance activity, up from 6.4% in April, while new work saw a smaller decline of 4% compared to 9.4% previously.\n\n8.30am: Dr Martens targets growth in US direct-to-customer market\n\nDr Martens has published a bare trading update prior to its AGM meeting this morning.\n\nThe classic British footwear company said that \"trading since the start of this financial year has been in line with expectations and our guidance for (financial 2025) remains unchanged\".\n\nThe first quarter is typically \"the smallest period of our financial year, representing the end of the Spring/Summer season\", said the group, adding that the current financial year will be weighted to the second half.\n\n\"The upcoming Autumn/Winter 24 season remains a key focus,\" said Dr Martens, with detailed trading plans currently being implemented.\n\nDr Martens is targeting target positive direct-to-customer growth in the US in the second half of the current financial year.\n\n\"Work on our cost action plan is ongoing and we will provide a detailed update at our first half results in November.\"\n\nShares were up 1.6% in opening exchanges.\n\n8.25am: Blue chips wobble\n\nMarkets dipped their toes into the red in opening trades despite pre-market data pointing to a strong start.\n\nThe FTSE 100 is currently a handful of points lower at 8,191, with Rolls-Royce Group plc, BAE Systems PLC (LSE:BA.) and Antofagasta plc among the worst performers.\n\n8.10am: Labour has inherited improving economy, GDP data shows\n\nBritain's economy grew by 1.4% year on year in May, outstripping the expected growth rate of 1.2% and doubling April's 0.7% gain.\n\nMonth on month, gross domestic product grew by 0.4%, an upside surprise following a zero-growth period in April.\n\n\"This should be a boon for the new Labour government with growth now likely to outstrip the OBR's 2024 GDP forecasts, partially offsetting some of the projected increase in interest rate costs,\" said Deutsche Bank's chief UK economist Sanjay Raja.\n\nAccording to Rob Morgan, chief investment analyst at Charles Stanley (LSE:CAY): \"The UK's economic scorecard shows significant room for improvement under the incoming Labour government.\n\n\"The UK economy has been subdued coming out of the "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9717113", "eventUri": "eng-9717113", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-28", "textStart": 13855, "textEnd": {"uri": "2024-07-416911993", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:06:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:06:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:00:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/cheap-sales-debt-foreign-takeovers-040048433.html", "title": "Cheap sales, debt and foreign takeovers: how privatisation changed the water industry", "body": "There was a time when privatised British water companies were as unpopular as they are now. During the hot summer of 1995, the managing director of Yorkshire Water, Trevor Newton, achieved notoriety when he urged customers to use less of his company's product by issuing a motivational message: \"I personally have not had a bath or shower for three months.\"\n\nAfter a round of jokes about \"the filthy rich\" - because megabucks pay for water company bosses was also in the headlines in those days - Newton invited the press to watch him washing with a flannel and bowl. It later emerged he had been popping out of Yorkshire for a soak at his parents' and in-laws' homes.\n\nRelated: Rise in sewage pollution from Thames Water's ageing treatment works\n\nThe serious aspect of the farce was that, just as now, the public was outraged by the mismatch between rewards for investors and the standard of service being provided by a privatised utility. Yorkshire had just paid a \u00a350m dividend to shareholders and yet the city of Bradford was at risk of running dry. A new grid was behind schedule and the company was reduced to transporting water by tanker through the Dales. \"Public anger exploded,\" recalled Sir Ian Byatt, the first head of the Office of Water Services, or Ofwat, the regulatory body created at privatisation in 1989, in his account of his career.\n\nThe saga also underlined the rotten state of the water infrastructure, the reason given for privatisation in the first place. The UK was regarded as the \"dirty man of Europe\" on account of pollution on beaches and in rivers. Spending by the industry on overhauling its pipes and sewage-treatment works had been falling from the mid-1970s to the mid-1980s and now the UK had to meet new European Community standards on pollution.\n\nMargaret Thatcher's administration, which had already privatised British Telecom and British Gas, decided only private capital and stock market ownership could deliver improvements. \"Much emotive nonsense was talked along the lines of, 'Look, she's even privatising the rain that falls from the heavens',\" wrote Thatcher in her memoirs. \"I used to retort that the rain may come from the Almighty but he did not send the pipes, plumbing and engineering to go with it.\"\n\nMore than three decades later, that same infrastructure requires a big upgrade, with bills to soar when Ofwat outlines the regime for the next five years on Thursday. In the meantime, the 10 English and Welsh water and wastewater companies have paid \u00a378bn in dividends since 1989, and accumulated \u00a360bn in debt. Meanwhile, the biggest of the lot, Thames Water, is at risk of temporary renationalisation. Only three of the 10 are still listed on the stock market. Meanwhile, the industry has become synonymous with mismanagement, corporate greed and pollution, as a string of sewage spills, water leaks and hefty fines led to deep public anger. How did we get here?\n\nRelated: Thames Water to tap investors for funds as it will run out of cash by next June\n\nSold on the cheap\n\nTo make privatisation happen in December 1989 - a month after the fall of the Berlin Wall - the government cancelled all the long-term debt owed by the previous water authorities and injected cash into the new companies as a \"green dowry\". Such exercises meant the net proceeds to the Treasury, even after selling the companies for a total of \u00a37.6bn, was roughly zero.\n\nThere was, though, the usual quick win for investors in the stock market listings: shares in the 10 companies rose 20% on average within a month. Half the small investors, encouraged to buy with the slogan \"You could be an H2Owner\", took their profits and sold their shares within a year. It was a period of corporate exuberance, lampooned by Harry Enfield's \"Loadsamoney\" character.\n\nBut extra spending did arrive. Investment roughly doubled in the four years after the sellout, from \u00a33bn a year to \u00a36bn. Privatisation fans could also argue that the discipline of a stock market listing, plus a smack from an independent regulator, could force underperformers to improve. After Yorkshire's shambles in 1995, Ofwat sent in investigators, which led to a management clear-out. By the end of decade, the company was top of the class for performance. Byatt also proposed that Yorkshire should return \u00a340m to customers in the form of price cuts and \"after some discussion, it concurred\".\n\nRelated: How Tory neglect flooded Britain's rivers with sewage\n\nBut it was immediately obvious that the companies had been sold far too cheaply. Customers' bills went up by a third in the first five years on the assumption at sale that the companies would need ready access to cash to fund the step-up in investment. Debt levels, it was thought originally, would comprise a maximum of only 35% of the value of the assets - the leverage, or gearing, ratio. The bond market, however, was willing to lend far greater sums to monopoly businesses with captive customers.\n\nAnd, strange as it may now sound, the regulator was keen to see financial gearing rise. The rationale was that savings from lower funding costs would be passed to customers in the form of lower bills. Ofwat's first five-yearly price review in 1994 slowed the bill rises imagined at privatisation; the second, in 1999, cut bills by an average of 12%.\n\nThe companies were happy to play the debt game. Some, flush with rising share prices and access to cheap capital, caught the diversification bug in the go-go 1990s. Thames won contracts to run water networks as far away as Indonesia and Chile. Welsh Water lost a packet by buying hotels and country clubs. In 2000, Anglian Water bought a construction company.\n\nTakeover games\n\nThen there were the takeover games, which began when the government cancelled its golden shares in the 10 companies in 1995. Northumbrian Water was bought by Lyonnaise des Eaux of France. Scottish Power bought Southern Water. Enron of the US - before it crashed in scandalous style in 2001 - bought Wessex Water. Water companies were not allowed to buy one another, but some adopted the fashionable notion of \"multi utilities\" and bought regional electricity suppliers, which were privatised in 1990. North West Water bought its local supplier to become United Utilities and Welsh Water took over South Wales Electricity, restyling itself as Hyder.\n\nNone of this activity was slowed by a windfall tax on the privatised utilities, water included, imposed by the incoming Labour government in 1997. Thames, for example, was sold for \u00a3922m at privatisation but was valued by the stock market at \u00a32.9bn in July 1997; Severn Trent had risen from \u00a3849m to \u00a33bn.\n\nBy the end of that first decade, the privatised water sector was changed beyond recognition. This newspaper reflected in 1999 on \"the mixed effects of water privatisation\". On one hand, too much of the extra profits had been \"dissipated in ill-advised diversifications, excess dividends and unearned mega-increases in boardroom pay\". On the other, \"a lot of money was invested in improving the infrastructure, so that we now have much improved drinking water\".\n\nThe deal-making kept coming. Thames was bought in 2000 by the German utility RWE, which paid \u00a34.3bn in cash and assumed \u00a32.5bn of debt. The takeover price of \u00a312.15 a share represented a fivefold increase from the 240p at which all 10 water companies were sold in 1989. Foreign capital continued to chase UK utilities and, in the spirit of times, that was seen as an excellent thing. New Labour was not going to mess with the model.\n\nPanic stations\n\nWhat followed was a critical turning point. In the early 2000s, Railtrack, after a series of horrendous fatal accidents on the railways, was forced into receivership and turned into Network Rail. Then British Energy, owner of the bulk of the country's nuclear plants, had to be bailed out.\n\nBoth events caused political panic, with the City doing its best to stoke fears that foreign capital would evaporate if owners were seen to be short-changed by government action (the unmerited allegation at Railtrack). In the wings, the water sector was still complaining bitterly that the supposed toughness of Ofwat's 1999 price review left it with insufficient incentives to invest.\n\nThe result was two actions that, with hindsight, accelerated financial risk-taking. First, in 2002, Ofwat extended the water companies' operating licences, which were due to expire in 2014. In their place, 25-year rolling licences were granted. \"The longer notice period will enable companies and their investors to plan ahead more securely,\" said Philip Fletcher, the late head of Ofwat. That was the hope, but the reform also insulated underperformers from any medium-term threat of being replaced.\n\nThen, in 2004, the next five-yearly price review was widely seen as a giveaway to the companies: bills were increased by 20%. Water was seen as even more attractive for investors.\n\nAt that point, takeover action went into overdrive. New buyers were not other utilities, but financial buyers - investment banks, infrastructure funds, pension funds. Macquarie's fateful \u00a38bn acquisition of Thames from RWE happened in 2006. So did the takeover of the parent of Anglian by a group of Canadian and Australian pension funds. In 2007, Southern Water fell to a consortium including JP Morgan Asset Management after a tussle with US investment bank Goldman Sachs. Kelda Group, the owner of Yorkshire Water, was bought by a consortium including Citigroup and HSBC.\n\nFormer regulators have pinpointed this period as one in which the game changed. Byatt wrote in his book A Regulator's Sign Off: Changing the Taps in Britain: \"Private equity infrastructure capital showed the hard face of capitalism, involving leveraged buyouts and short-term policies, namely high borrowing and high dividends, meriting widespread criticism for its lack of transparency and for its financial engineering.\"\n\nJonson Cox, who had spells running Yorkshire and Anglian before he was chair of Ofwat from 2012 until 2022, told a House of Lords committee soon after leaving the regulator: \"In the 2000s, investment banks began to realise that there was an opportunity to acquire the water company assets and to put significantly more leverage on to those capital structures. I was not at Ofwat at that time. I have disagreed with that approach and I think it is very unfortunate that it happened.\"\n\nInvestment banks created skewed incentives, he argued, and created \"the predisposition of thinking of water companies as financial assets\".\n\nRelated: Ruling paves way for businesses and public to sue water firms over sewage\n\nFinancial engineering on steroids\n\nShortly after Macquarie bought it, Thames embarked on a \"whole business securitisation\" in 2007 - a fundraising whose banal name belied its aggressive approach. A previously staid business of pipes and sewage treatment works was packaged into a complex corporate structure, with eight layers of ownership - including a subsidiary in the Cayman Islands, which allowed debt to be layered on debt, like the tiers in a wedding cake.\n\nSuddenly, leverage ratios of 50% or 60% went higher than 80% at some companies taken off the stock market. As Thames explained in 2018, this byzantine corporate structure let it borrow more, with the approval of the ratings agencies: \"A higher level of leverage is possible at an investment grade credit rating.\"\n\nMacquarie has defended its use of a whole business securitisation at Thames, saying it was \"very common\" at the time. \"It was a UK water utility product that was invented, advised and constructed by UK banks,\" Martin Bradley, the company's head of infrastructure, told Infrastructure Investor magazine last year.\n\nFor investors in Macquarie funds that cashed in via a staggered sale of Thames in 2017, he pointed to annual gross returns of 12%-13%, which he argued were in line with regulatory guidance in the 2005-09 period. \"There's nothing in our returns that I'm embarrassed about,\" Bradley argued.\n\nThe Australian bank has also defended its broader stewardship of Thames, saying the company \"undertook a record level of investment despite the returns allowed by Ofwat being reduced\".\n\nThe legacy of the sector's debt binge in the mid-2000s era lives on, however. Southern Water, which adopted a whole business securitisation in 2003, had to be rescued in 2021 in what now looks like a miniature version of the financial crisis now engulfing Thames. Controversially, the buyer at Southern was Macquarie, which injected \u00a31bn in new equity to recapitalise the business.\n\nIt was only belatedly that Ofwat woke up to the dangers of overborrowing. Powers to stop the payment of dividends if they would risk the company's financial resilience were introduced only last year.\n\nOne core question about the post-privatisation era is whether the gravitational shift from sensibly capitalised public companies on the stock market to heavily leveraged private entities contributed to the sector's woeful environmental record.\n\nIs it, for example, a coincidence that the two most heavily fined companies over the years - Thames and Southern - were also the two with the most aggressive financing structures?\n\nDebt, it should be said, has also been used for its original purpose of accelerating investment, complementing the portion funded from bills. Overall, post-privatisation investment has totalled \u00a3190bn. But the overuse of financial leverage, with the aim of maximising returns for shareholders, is undeniable.\n\nCurrent Ofwat chief executive, David Black, addressed the point last year when Thames' financial crisis became acute: \"For most companies, debt has been a prudent low-cost source of finance with low interest rates fixed for the long-term,\" he said. \"However, some companies borrowed too much, most obviously Thames Water. The risk for this - and for correcting this - belongs to the company and its shareholders.\"\n\nTherein lies one huge tension at the heart of the recent ruling from Ofwat on the companies' business plans for the next five years. Investment is needed on a massive scale and customers' bills are going up substantially, whatever happens. But will the regulator really make the worst debt addicts pay for their borrowing binges?", "source": {"uri": "uk.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! Its precaruous situation is a concern to the new government.\n\nThames Water's draft business plan for the eighth asset management period (AMP8), between 2025 and 2030, promises \u00a319.8bn investment, including \u00a34.5bn on enhancements. If this gets sign off from regulator Ofwat next week it will be engaging with potential investors and creditors to seek new equity and extend its liquidity runway.\n\nThe annual report states that poor asset health a \"key root cause\" of Thames Water's performance challenges.\n\n\"The declining health of our ageing infrastructure has taken place over decades as we have stretched the life of our assets,\" it further states. \"This has helped to keep bills down for customers but it has also meant we have been repairing assets rather than replacing them and this is only sustainable for a limited period. Poor asset health today impacts our financial position through performance penalties, which subsequently results in less money to invest in improvement.\"\n\nBeyond the \u00a33.5bn needed to hold asset deterioration stable across its \u00a3147bn asset base, Thames Water says that reversing the decline will take a programme that runs across multiple AMP cycles - suggesting a minimum of 10 years. It says that it is \"making progress towards that ambition\".\n\nRisk in delivery renewal programme\n\nDesign and delivery of capital projects is listed as one of Thames Water's principal risks and uncertainties as it is responsible for the sector's largest capital infrastructure renewal programme. The risk to this has been identified as coming from its ability to resource and access specialist contractors and its ability to effectively control \"such a large and complex delivery portfolio\".\n\nIt says that this risk is increasing and it has experienced delivery challenges in AMP7 (2020-2025) \"due to the change of delivery model and impact of Covid-19\". Increased construction costs have also impinged on its ability to deliver all of its AMP7 scope. This \"will instead need to be delivered in the next regulatory period, on top of the largest investment portfolio in the sector's history\".\n\nThames Water is putting in place a turnaround plans that seeks to improve its end-to-end capital delivery process, including prioritisation, sponsorship and programme management.\n\nIt is also insourcing capability through targeted recruitment and utilising industry standard project methodology to measure and track the effectiveness of its people and processes.\n\n'Critical risk'\n\nThames Water's debt pile has topped \u00a315bn after investors siphoned out money over recent years and have been withholding on reinvestment, with a \u00a3500M promise not delivered in March as conditions hadn't been met.\n\nThe new government is monitoring the financial situation and has been told by Whitehall officials that the potential of its failure - or the failure of any of its major assets - is a \"critical risk\" to the country, The Guardian reported this week.\n\nThe water company has 16M customers in London and the Thames Valley and it supplies over 2.5bn litres of potable water per day.\n\nThe condition of Coppermills water treatment works in north east London, which serves around 3M people, is of particular concern, according to the Guardian reporting.\n\nA spokesperson for the government said that it doesn't think nationalising the company is the right course of action. It is instead focused on holding water companies to account and improving systems, rather than allowing them to reward themselves.\n\nHowever, the Guardian reports that it has seen emergency plans that have been written up to turn Thames Water into a publicly-owned arm's length body under the state's special administration regime, if required.\n\nThe good news\n\nThames Water's annual report did provide some positive outlook in both financial and operational performance.\n\nThe overview of financial performance shows:\n\nOperational performance\n\n\"The challenges we face are well documented, but our operational and financial performance for the last year show good progress, and these positive results provide the right foundations on which to build and improve,\" Thames Water CEO Chris Weston said. \"\"We've delivered year-on-year improvements in our key water metrics, with leakage at its lowest ever level, and we're supporting more customers through our social tariffs.\n\n\"Revenue, EBITDA and operating cash flow all grew strongly, supporting a record \u00a32bn of investment in our infrastructure that will ultimately improve asset resilience, environmental performance, and customer service. Our teams should be immensely proud of what they've delivered during a difficult year and for maintaining focus on what matters most to our customers.\"\n\nReaction\n\nInstitution of Civil Engineers interim associate director of policy David Hawkes said: \"The challenges faced by the water sector are complex. None will have a one-size-fits-all solution.\n\n\"However, regardless of whether companies are in public or private ownership, the new government's priorities should be those that the ICE has been advising for some time. The regulatory system must be reformed to align with new priorities like net zero and there needs to be a longer-term approach to investment, maintenance, and planning - the current five-year cycle is too short.\n\n\"The role of nature-based solutions in delivering a better water infrastructure system should be considered, and finally, rebuilding trust between the public, water companies, and regulators must be a priority. The company is allowed an additional \u00a3189 million to continue its programme to improve the taste, smell and appearance of its water.\n\n\"Overall, to deliver its performance commitments and legal obligations, our draft decision provides United Utilities with a total expenditure allowance of \u00a312 billion over the 2025-30 period. This is \u00a34.5 billion more than the company was provided with in the current price review period (2020-25).\n\n\"We consider that United Utilities can deliver its performance commitments and obligations for less cost than it requested, and our proposed allowances are 17 per cent lower than the company's plan.\"\n\nUnited Utilities published its business plan for 2025-30 in October 2023. We have incentivised it to go beyond its performance targets to achieve even better outcomes for customers and the environment. Events including this year's Boat Race and Henley Royal Regatta faced warnings over levels of E coli in the water - and pollution incidents increased to 350, up on 331 last year.\n\nThe firm has said it is looking for fresh funding to maintain and update its infrastructure after investors pulled the plug on \u00a3500m of emergency cash earlier this year; which leaves Keir Starmer with a significant dilemma: whether or not to nationalise (but more on that later...).\n\nStill, there's no need to panic just yet. The company's financial travails - writ large in its latest results - are highly unlikely to end in the taps running dry. We aren't going to witness emergency standpipes in the street and queues outside Tesco for multipacks of Evian.\n\nThe real pain for the consumer is coming in the form of much higher bills. Thames Water has managed to declare an \"underlying\" profit of \u00a3140m for the year to 31 March, an improvement of \u00a3270m on the previous year, largely down to increasing what it charged customers. Those underlying profits exclude \u00a3152m worth of one-off costs incurred during the year.\n\nThat is by no means the end of it. The company thinks it has enough cash to keep going for just 11 months. Warnings about its future as a \"going concern\" are splashed all over the accounts, including from the company's auditors. The company also records the payment of \u00a3195.8m in dividends.\n\nGiven the dire situation - and the knock-on effects on its customers - the bonuses handed out to top bosses seem tasteless in the extreme.\n\nCEO Chris Weston, who was appointed on 8 January, received \u00a3437,000, including a bonus of \u00a3195,000, for fewer than three months work. Finance chief Alistair Cockburn was paid \u00a31.33m for a year's service, which included a spell as co-CEO. His package was fattened by a \u00a3446,000 annual bonus. Thames Water's pain is being shared widely - just not in the boardroom.\n\nBut there is more to leave a sour taste in the mouths of consumers in the weeds of Thames Water's annual report. I turned to the section marked \"customer performance\": only to discover that bad debt levels are twice the industry average and \"this has to improve\". That's right: it's all our fault.\n\nThat this river of bad news is still running is in part down to the fact that the government wants no part of nationalisation, even though polls suggest that it would be highly popular with the public. Rachel Reeves does not want Thames Water's debt on her books. Business secretary Jonathan Reynolds does not want to be on the hook for the inevitable increases in water bills in the capital. Environment secretary Steve Reed does not want to cop the flak the next time untreated sewage is pumped into an unsuspecting watercourse.\n\nThis gives Weston a certain amount of breathing room; but not much. In March, existing investors - including sovereign wealth funds in Abu Dhabi and China, along with pension funds in Canada and the UK - described the company as \"uninvestable\", pulling out of plans to serve up \u00a3500m of emergency funding and \u00a33.25bn over the next five years. Omers, a Canadian pension fund, has written down the value of its holding to zero.\n\nWeston is going to have to look elsewhere for cash. He's been talking up the prospects of doing that, claiming he's held discussions and received expressions of interest. However, he's having to wait on regulator Ofwat's verdict on the 59 per cent extra he wants customers to stump up for between 2025 and 2030. The watchdog may also have thoughts on those dividends and bonuses.\n\nOfwat bosses are going to find approving such a package a challenge, given that they are already facing questions on how Thames Water's infrastructure has been allowed to degrade to such an extent. This is something for one or more select committees to get their teeth into when their memberships have been selected. There will be blood.\n\nBut you don't really need a full-scale parliamentary inquiry to ascertain how we made it to this particular impasse. Regulators slept while the scales tipped far too far in favour of investors, financial engineers and the City.\n\nHow does this end? It's hard to see Weston securing the funds he needs on terms that will be acceptable to Ofwat. Investing in Thames Water in its current state represents a high risk. If I were sat on an investment firm's risk committee I'd have my red \"no, not under any circumstances\" stamp at the ready.\n\nI wouldn't be at all surprised to see some sort of recovery vehicle being set up, with the backing of the taxpayer, albeit at arm's length. In the interim, Reynolds might be wise to pick up the phone to Stephen Byers, a predecessor of his (albeit with a different title) who had a nasty post-privatisation migraine of his own to deal with in the form of Railtrack, which eventually became (the state-owned) Network Rail.\n\nNone of which changes the fact that billpayers are going to be spitting with rage and disbelief when their bills kick in the door.
